Sir,

I have the honour to report that the Principal of the R.C. Indian Residential School at this Agency, complained to me of some trouble the school was experiencing with their hot water system, for which they could not find the cause. I engaged a local machinist, Mr. E. Rotherham, to visit the school and ascertain the trouble, and he has reported to me that there is a leak in the steam coil inside the hot water tank which is preventing the water from heating. This hot water tank is constructed of heavy boiler plate iron, and, as it has no manhole, by which one could get to the interior, it will be necessary to have one cut out before any repairs can be made to the steam coil inside. Mr. Rotherham has not the necessary tools for this work and it will be necessary to bring in a man from Lloydminster to do it; but as the school in the meantime is without hot water, I would ask you to telegraph me authority to have the trouble remedied. I do not think the job will be a very expensive one, probably under $50.00.

I enclose a rough sketch which I had Mr. Rotherham prepare for me, which I believe will aid the Department in understanding the matter.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith Voucher No. 325, in favour of R. F. Spies, Lloydminster, Sask., for $152.88, for repairs to the hot water tank at the Onion Lake Roman Catholic Indian Residential School here.

This work has cost more than at first estimated, for the reason that when the manhole was cut in the tank so that an examination could be made, it was found that the coils, eleven in number, were so completely corroded as to make repairs impossible, and it was therefore necessary to purchase all new material for these.

I may add that a very satisfactory job has been made, and the principal of the school has expressed himself as being very pleased with it.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,
[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Ottawa.

ONION LAKE R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on May 6th, and made a general inspection of the school and outbuildings. There are 119 pupils enrolled, 56 boys and 63 girls, all of whom
ONION LAKE R.C., INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

whom were present on the day of my visit. There were two pupils sick in bed under the doctor's care, but the general health amongst the others appeared to be very good, and they presented a clean and well nourished appearance. The pupilage is divided into three classes - senior, intermediate, and junior. There are three Sisters who act as teachers. Sister St. Wilfred, in charge of the senior room, has a first class Alberta certificate. Sister Stebbing, intermediate classroom, and Sister St. Delmas, in charge of the junior classroom, each have Quebec certificates. The staff appear to be quite efficient.

The girls are given training in cooking, sewing, knitting, and laundry work, and during the summer months, in the milking of cows. The boys assist on the farm and in the care of the stock. They are given ample meals of wholesome nourishing food, including soup, meat, eggs, potatoes, bread, butter, puddings, tea, and milk. The diet is varied.

I found the school building very clean and tidy throughout. This is a comparatively new building, but the work on the building was not performed in a satisfactory way. The plaster is cracked, and has fallen off in many places, and the paint on the outside of the building has peeled off to the boards. The lighting, heating, and plumbing appears to be satisfactory. The fire hose and equipment in the interior of the building is in good shape. A large 20 horse power Fairbanks-Morse engine, together with a force pump, is installed in a separate building for fire protection, but this unit cannot be used as there is no belt tightener provided.
ONION LAKE R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

and when they start the engine they cannot keep the belt on the pulleys. A belt tightener with a pulley with a 20" face, together with a shift lever, should be provided in order to make this unit workable. There is ample hose provided in connection with this plant, but it is absolutely useless, for the purpose for which it was provided, in its present condition.

There is also need for a small storage cellar in the building to enable them to keep milk and food stuffs. There was no room provided for this purpose. It could be easily added to the west side of the kitchen.

If burlap were provided in the hallways and stairways, it would be a great protection to the plaster in this building, which appears to be of a poor quality and easily knocked off.

The farm at this school is in charge of a practical farmer and so far has been very satisfactory. They have 170 acres under cultivation. Last year they raised 4,400 bus. of grain, 2,190 of which was wheat. They had 1,375 bus. of potatoes and a large quantity of other roots and vegetables sufficient for their requirements. They also grew 45 tons of sunflowers.

There are 10 cows milking, and 2 to freshen, and they already have 8 calves this spring. These animals are all Ayrshires. They have 62 pigs and about 80 hens. Their henhouse is rather small for the requirements of an institution of this size, and it should have at least another section added.

It was noted that a new ice house has been built since my last visit. It was also noted that a brick chimney...
ONION LAKE R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

chimney has been built from the laundry, which adds a great measure of safety and convenience.

The work at this school appears to be progressing in a very satisfactory way. The Rev. Father Portier is in charge as Principal. He appears to be a good business man, and is taking a keen interest in the welfare of the school. He is assisted by Mr. Balduc as Farmer, and Mr. Chartier as engineer. The interior work is performed by thirteen Sisters including the Superior, Rev. Sister St. Ferdinand, who has had many years experience in managing Indian schools.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various schools in the Onion Lake Agency which were inspected by Mr. Murison.

I would draw your attention to what the Inspector says regarding the St. Lawrence Day School on the Cold Lake Reserve. I concur in his remarks.

The work at the other schools appears to be carried on in a satisfactory manner.

You will note the Inspector's remarks regarding the 20 h.p. Fairbanks-Morse engine, with force pump, at the R.C. Residential School, namely that it is of no use without a belt tightener. This should have been provided by the school authorities themselves. We cannot attempt to look after the hundred and one details in connection with these schools, unless we make up our minds that we are to manage them entirely and be responsible for everything.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 29, 1931.

Sir:

I have your 309-11 of the 22nd instant, enclosing Mr. Inspector Murison's report on his recent inspection of the various schools in the Onion Lake agency.

Regarding the Inspector's remarks that the 20 N. P. Fairbanks-Morse engine at the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School requires a belt tightener, I have to say the Department is taking this matter up with Mr. Agent Turner, with the request that he have the school authorities arrange to have a belt tightener and pulley, together with a shift lever, provided, in order to make this unit workable. We are also drawing attention to the condition of the plaster which, the Inspector states, has fallen off in many places.

The Agent is also being written with reference to the various suggestions of the Inspector regarding matters that require attention at the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, May 29, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Murison, in a report on his recent inspection of the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School, states that the 20 H. P. Fairbanks-Morse engine, used for fire protection, is in an unworkable condition. He states that a belt tightener with a pulley with 20 inch face, together with a shift lever, should be provided in order to make this unit workable. I have therefore requested that you will take this matter up with the school authorities at once and arrange with them to install the necessary equipment to place the unit in a workable condition. This should be provided by the school authorities themselves. The Inspector states that, while ample hose has been supplied in connection with the fire protection, it is absolutely useless for the purpose at present, until the engine has been placed in good condition.

The Inspector further draws attention to the condition of the plaster which, he states, has cracked and fallen off in many places. I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding this matter, as well as any recommendation with reference to the necessity of repairs being carried out at the present time. If you recommend that any work be done in connection with the plastering, please state in what parts of the building it is required and the approximate cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

ONION LAKE, SASK.
I have the honour to refer to your letter of May 29th last, No. 115-8-5, with reference to Mr. Inspector Murray's on the R. C. Indian Residential School here, and, in reply to the first paragraph thereof, to state that I am still in correspondence with the Washburne-Morse Company with respect to one of their engines for this school which is unworkable. I have furnished them every bit of all the information it requires and believe that this trouble will be made right almost immediately.

With respect to the condition of the plaster at this school. Most of the damage has been done on the two stairways, east and west, from the basement to the second floor. There are also a few patches requiring an extra plastering and other parts of the building. The whole of this work can be done for, approximately, $25.00.

In connection with this work I would say that both the Reverend Principal and the Sister Superior urged me to ask the Department to have burlap placed throughout these halls and stairways, and, if the Department will see its way to do so I would certainly recommend having it put on. The quantity required would be about 200 yards, which at 50¢ per yard would amount to $100.00 and, together with an allowance of $60.00 for the necessary moulding and labour would cost a total of, approximately, $160.00.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 6, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, regarding the repairs required to the plaster in various parts of the building at the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have the repairs to this plaster carried out. It is noted you estimate the cost to be approximately $25. After the repairs have been completed, please forward a certified account, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

Relating to the request of the Reverend Principal to have burlap installed throughout the halls and stairways, I have to say that we have no funds available for this purpose, and this work will have to stand over for the present.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Mr. W.W. Kennedy M.P.

Deputy Supt.-Gen. of Indian Affairs,
Dept. of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In re claim of Brown and Hudson.
In re erection of Indian School at Onion Lake in or about the year 1927.

Relative to the above claim I submit the following observations:

1. The merits of this claim were originally presented to your Department by J.T. Thorsen, ex M.P.

2. Latterly the claim was gone into by our Firm, and certain facts presented to your Department.

A careful perusal of all correspondence impresses upon me the importance of ascertaining the following facts, namely: When the Department decided to erect a new school in the area in question was it the original intention to have the school erected at or adjoining the site of the old school at Onion Lake? If so, when was the decision arrived at or communicated in any way in respect to the erection of a school some distance from the former site?

As this phase of the matter seems very important to me I interviewed the Minister, the Hon. T.G. Murphy when going through Winnipeg last week and obtained from him the necessary authority directed to you to make available to me all information or correspondence relating to the erection of the Indian School in question.

For that purpose I enclose herewith the original authority signed by Mr. Murphy, and would very much appreciate receiving the following information:

1. Was it the original intention to erect a new school at or near the site of the old school at Onion Lake? or was the erection at that point considered?

2. If such was the original intention when was the change of the location to the present site of the new school decided upon?
Will you kindly furnish me with all Departmental correspondence and memoranda relevant in any way to the question of the site on which the school was to be located or any changes in respect thereto.

The Minister advised me that he would be returning through Winnipeg before very long and I arranged to obtain this very necessary information from you in the meantime so I could then take the whole matter up with him in detail.

If I can have this information at your earliest convenience it would be very much appreciated, also any relevant facts which occur to you relevant to the question whether or not the mistake of Brown and Hudson as to the location of the school was an honest mistake.

I am

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

W. W. Kennedy
M.P.O.,
Winnipeg South Centre.

August 25, 1931.

Dear Sir,

Re: Erection of Indian School at Onion Lake.

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 18th instant and note your enquiries.

In reply I beg to say that a site at or near the old school at Onion Lake had never been decided upon for the erection of the building in question. The original and only intention was to erect the said building on such a site as might be selected as being particularly suited for the purpose wherever that might be.

I am enclosing departmental correspondence and memoranda relative to the question of the site on which the school was to be located.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

W.W. Kennedy, Esq., K.C., LL.B., M.P.,
Messrs. Kennedy, Kennedy & Kennedy,

I have the honour to report with respect to the lighting plant at the Onion Lake Roman Catholic Indian Residential School.

The school could obtain lights only whilst the engine was running and reported to me to this effect. I had Mr. E. Rotherham, local electrician, look over the plant, and he reported that the batteries were used up; that many of them had broken plates and that all were defective. The Reverend Father Portier, the principal, wanted immediate action, and, as, at the time of our conversation, he was just leaving for Lloydminster, I advised him to speak to the Indian Commissioner over the telephone. He demurred at doing this and said he would rather telegraph, and asked me to draft a telegram for him, which I did. On one or two occasions since then I have asked Father Portier if he had yet received any word of new batteries being supplied; and on the last occasion, yesterday, he told me that he had ordered a new set from Edmonton, and that they would be installed in about two weeks time. The Reverend Principal also asked me to write the Department requesting it to bear the cost of this installation, and this I am pleased to do, as it was really imperative to have these batteries replaced.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Hon. Sir,

Please let me come to you today with a confession to make and a request to present, and the feeling that you will approve what I have done and grant my demand.

A few weeks ago, it was noticed that our lighting system was failing. I tried to get expert advice and service, but all we could do was in vain, and progressively it came so bad that we have not any light and any water pressure unless we keep the engine running all the time, the batteries are completely gone for and have to be replaced. Mr. Turner, the Indian Agent, came to verify the bad predicament in which we are, and admitted that we could not go on any longer that way, and decided we had to notify Mr. Grisham at Regina and to make an appeal to him; Mr. Turner himself wrote this telegraphic message: "Storage batteries absolutely used up at the R.C. Res. School; can obtain light only whilst engine running. Many of the #12345 jars have broken plates. Kindly arrange for batteries to be replaced." The message was sent, but we did not get any answer, and in the impossibility of waiting any more, taking the advice of Mr. Turner and with his approbation I thought it was my duty to go ahead and to buy new batteries. I am just coming back from Edmonton where I made the deal, and I am expecting these batteries to be soon installed.

Well that's what I have done, the necessity was patent and pressing, I had no time to communicate with you and to obtain your approbation, so I hope confidently that you wont refuse your approbation and now the granting of a special help in order to pay the bill. Memorandum

The Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

With reference to the letter of the 9th instant addressed to the Right Honourable the Prime Minister by Mr. Sam Brown, Contractor, Winnipeg, regarding a claim against the Department arising out of his contract for building the St. Anthony Indian School, Onion Lake Reserve, Saskatchewan, on the alleged ground that the site was changed after the tenders were invited for the building, necessitating additional expenses on his part, I beg to give you the following facts covering the statement made by Mr. Brown in the said letter.

Mr. Brown states, "That the advertisement calling for tenders for the above school stipulated Onion Lake No. 2 School in Saskatchewan." This statement is not correct. The advertisement inviting tenders for this building provided that the tenders should be addressed as follows—“Tenders for St. Anthony’s Indian Residential School on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, Saskatchewan.”

Mr. Brown further states, “Plans and specifications also stipulated Onion Lake School.” This statement is not correct. The heading of the specifications is as follows—“Specifications of work to be done and materials furnished in the erection and completion of the St. Anthony’s Indian Residential School on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, Saskatchewan.”

Mr. Brown further states, “That the specifications instructed bidders to communicate via Long Turner, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, for all information relating to the site of the school. There was a note preceding the specifications that for all information with reference to the site of the proposed building the contractor should refer to Indian Agent Long Turner, Onion Lake, Sask. The specifications provided that before submitting a proposal the bidders shall carefully examine the plans and specifications, visit the site of the proposed work and ascertain for themselves the nature of the soil to be excavated and the amount of excavation required, and also inform themselves as to all existing conditions. With respect to this statement by Mr. Brown he points out that the specifications provided no site reference to the site of the proposed building contractors were to refer to Indian Agent Turner. Pursuant to this direction Mr. Brown wrote to Mr. Long Turner and received a reply stating that the site for the new school was about 30 miles North of Lloydminster. The location as given by the Indian Agent was only of a general character and could not have been intended by him or relied upon by Mr. Brown in defining the boundaries of the site. It is impossible from such information, nor could the information be given me in the exact site by correspondence with an accurate plan of the portion of the Reserve on which the school was to be built. I may say that the Department has never considered any other site for this building but the one on which it is located.

On March 20th, 1927, the Deputy Superintendent General telegraphed to Commissioner Graham asking that arrangements had been made for the site, and on March 31st a telegram was received from the Indian Commissioner stating that an excellent situation for the school had been chosen by the Inspector and the Principal, approximately 1½ miles North of the South-west corner of Seesamkooch, good spring, good farming land and lake. This telegram was confirmed in a letter of the same date from Mr. Graham. In this letter he further states that Mr. Hamilton advised him that the Reserve Principal had selected the site mentioned in his telegram two years ago, and it was situated in the best farming land on the reserve.

Mr. Hamilton, Inspector of Construction during the erection of this school, checked the mileage from Lloydminster to the site by the speedometer on one of the trucks and found it to be a little less than 50 miles.

Mr. Brown further states, "that the contract specified that the building was to be erected at Onion Lake, Sask. My tender was based on the above information that the building was to be erected at Onion Lake". This statement is not correct as above stated both the specifications and the advertisement inviting tenders stated that the building was to be erected on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, Sask. Mr. Brown's tender was made and his offer accepted before the contract was signed, and he could not have been misled by the wording of the formal contract which designated this building as the Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, Sask. The latter is merely an abbreviation of the fuller description in the specifications on which Mr. Brown had already tendered.

Mr. Brown further states, "that for reasons over which I had no control this building was not erected at Onion Lake, but was built 6 miles from the town, which resulted in higher costs as conditions were much different from those outlined in Letter No. 1's letter to me." The description given by Mr. Lang Turner in his letter to Mr. Brown was as correct a description as could be given by letter as the site is about 6 miles or 30 miles south of Lloydminster. There is a lake about 200 yards from the school site, and a fine spring 150 yards from the school building. This spring is at present supplying all water requirements for the school. Most of the gravel used by Mr. Brown was procured within a mile of the job.

Mr. Brown apparently did not visit the site to ascertain for himself the necessary particulars as provided for by the specifications. He made arrangements with Mr. Lang to send a man to look over the ground on his behalf. It is said that the man was told at Onion Lake that the site was right beside the old school at Onion Lake. It is not alleged that this man was told by the Indian Agent. The Department can take no responsibility for any information given to this man by anyone else as to the location of this site. Mr. Turner, in his letter to Mr. Brown above referred to, apparently volunteered some information or gave it on request from Mr. Brown as to the availability of gravel, water and lumber. As Mr. Brown in the specifications was referred to the Indian Agent for the location of the site only, and Mr. Brown was requested to visit the site and ascertain the facts for himself, the Department can take no responsibility as to what correspondence passed between the Agent and Mr. Brown as to these matters.
As above stated, however, the information given by the Agent to Mr. Brown as to the availability of gravel and water and the site where the school was intended to be erected and was erected is substantially correct.

Referring to the last paragraph of Mr. Brown's letter, I beg to say that he has furnished the Department at different times with a statement of his claim for extras for moving the site and has been advised that in view of the facts that favourable consideration could not be given to his claim. When Mr. Brown first submitted his claim the same was referred to Mr. Hamilton, Inspector of Construction on this work, and I beg to quote from Mr. Hamilton's letter as follows:

"In answer to your letter of the 5th which was received today asking information re claims of Brown and Hudson as to change of site of the R. C. Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, I will give you my opinion on the several items in the order as they appear in your letter."

Item No. 1. Building and furnishing camp $18,000.00.

In the first place the specifications call for the school to be erected on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, and that the bidders were supposed to visit the site of the proposed work and ascertain for themselves as to the existing conditions, the buildings referred to as bunk house, cook house, office for the company, also office for the Inspector did not cost them $600.00 altogether, and that they got a fair price for them when they were bought with them, and in my opinion it would have cost them far more if they had rented buildings.

Item No. 2. Hauling water. $400.00.

There is a lake about 300 yards from where the school site is and a fine spring about 150 yards from the building, and if Mr. Hudson had taken the interest in the work he should have had the spring tapped and installed a small engine and a pump at the spring and could have supplied all the water required for the work, also for drinking purposes. This spring is at present supplying all the water required for the school, and as for Mr. Turner saying that the water was right at the site he was correct, and in all my conversation with Mr. Turner he never mentioned any other site than the one where the school is located, and the water is far better.

Item No. 3. Difference in cost of gravel. $1,000.00.

All the gravel used in the building did not cost them more than $1.25 per yard as most of it was procured within a mile of the job and when the pit ran out they hauled from another pit from which they paid $1.25 per yard for hauling and 20¢ to the Agency, the reason the Government had to pay $1.75 for gravel was on account of most of the time being out harvesting. Mr. Hudson put their machines at hauling gravel and they made eight trips per day with each truck from the farthest pit.

Item No. 4. Hauling lumber and camp supplies.

The price charged for hauling lumber from Onion Lake was $3.00 per thousand, and the amount of lumber they received from Onion Lake was approximately 35,000 feet, but the balance of the 125,000 feet of lumber, namely about 90,000 they saved money on the hauling as the new school is...
is about seven miles closer to the railway than the old school site, and the above applies to the camp supplies.

Referring to the change of site they never mentioned anything to me about it till about the time the contracts had been signed and in talking with the Agent, Mr. Turner, at Onion Lake and also the authorities at the St. Anthony's School they told me that they had never considered having the school erected at the old site in Onion Lake.

There are some conditions that existed in the handling of the work in connection with the erection of the school which was anything but good management, and I feel every reason to believe as any loss which has occurred through the way the work was handled will have to be borne by him, but of course it was his own fault as he should have known the man he was sending there to handle the work.

I hope that the above explanation may be of assistance to you in deciding on the claim referred to, and in reference to the first clause of your letter of regret in having to trouble me in regard to the particulars, I am only too pleased to give you any assistance possible in getting the matter straightened out, for I am sure you must be near the end of your patience, and any other information I can give you will be cheerfully given. I beg to remain,

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

St. ANTHONY'S R.C. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I visited this school in the forenoon of October 20th. It is under the management of the Roman Catholic Church. The staff consists of the Reverend Father Portier, as Principal, Mr. L. Oullette, as Farmer, and C. Chartier, Engineer. There are also twelve Sisters of Charity, including three teachers, the Superior, cook, laundress, seamstress, and their necessary helpers. The school is well managed and I have always found it in a very creditable condition. The Provincial School Inspector speaks very favorable with regard to the results obtained in the -
obtained in the classroom work.

There are two stand pipes running from the basement to the top of the building connected with the pressure tanks for fire protection. Adequate hose are provided on each floor attached to the stand pipes. There are also fire extinguishers placed in easily accessible positions on each floor. Outside fire escapes are also provided which are easy of access. I examined the fire fighting equipment and found it all in good working order. In addition to the provision made for fighting fire in the interior of the building, there is a separate unit installed about fifty feet from the building, which includes a 25 H.P. Fairbanks-Morse engine and a pump with a capacity of 250 gallons per minute. Five hundred feet of hose are provided for this unit, so they are well equipped in this connection. The children receive frequent training in fire drill. I have seen the building evacuated in two minutes from the time the fire alarm sounded.

The paint on the exterior of the building has pretty well all peeled off, particularly on the West and North sides. Apparently this building was painted at the wrong season of the year, either that or an inferior quality of paint was used as it has been unsatisfactory from the beginning. I noticed that the plaster on the walls in the stairways was badly scaled and broken in places. Where there are so many children climbing these stairs several times daily it would appear necessary to have the plaster walls protected with burlap. This has never been done.

There are 640 acres of land set aside for the school. It is all fenced in with a four strand barbed wire fence strung on cedar posts. The crop consisted of 35 acres of wheat which yielded one thousand bushels, 45 acres of oats yielded 1900 bushels, 15 acres of rye and 50 acres of green feed. Forty-five acres of summer-fallow were prepared this
summer. They have a large garden which provided for their requirements. They took up 400 bushels of potatoes, although the garden was not as good as usual.

The live stock at the school consists of 46 cattle, 80 hogs, about 150 poultry, and 7 work horses. They milk 13 cows regularly. The cattle are grade Ayrshires. They are not a very good class of cattle in my opinion and I think the Principal would be well advised to dispose of them and get a good quality of Shorthorn or Holstein. Our experience has been that they give a larger flow of milk and are more profitable to raise.

I found the out-buildings in a good state of repair and the premises clean and tidy.

W. Maclean,
Inspector

Memorandum:

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

For a considerable part of yesterday afternoon I took up with Mr. Brown his claim with regard to the Onion Lake School. The basis of Mr. Brown's claim is that he was misled as to the location on which the school was to be erected and he endeavoured to place the blame on our Indian Agent. It was pointed out to Mr. Brown that the information given him by the Agent was correct and that if he had been misled in the matter it was due to his own negligence or to the negligence of the man he sent up to ascertain the exact location of the site.

Mr. Brown asked that the Department consent to arbitration of his claim. I pointed out to Mr. Brown that so far as I could see there was nothing to arbitrate and that even if he had an apparent claim I would not be in favour of leaving it to arbitration. I advised Mr. Brown that the Exchequer Court was the proper tribunal to adjudicate on any claim brought against the Government. I may say that this view has been concurred in by the Deputy Minister of Justice.

Mr. Brown now takes the position that even assuming that he had no legal claim, in view of the remoteness of the location for the erection of this school and the difficulty in getting full information to enable him to properly estimate the cost, and in view of the fact that it cost him, as he alleges, approximately $10,000 more than he got out of the contract, the Department having received the benefit of this excess, he
thinks as a matter of grace the Department might properly meet him halfway in his loss.

I may say that the Architect is of the opinion that the loss sustained was not due to the lowness of the tender but due rather to the inefficiency of the men that were associated with Mr. Brown in this contract.

I may say that it is not the practice of the Department to make such contributions as is now asked for by Mr. Brown. It is not altogether unusual for a contractor to occasionally lose money on a contract.

I advised Mr. Brown that if he should apply to the Attorney General for a fiat to sue the Department in respect of this claim, that, subject to your approval I would not oppose the granting of the fiat if the application were considered regular in other respects.

Mr. Brown desires to see you this morning in further reference to this matter.

Dear Sir:

Confirming my verbal reply to your letter of the 17th instant, in regard to the set of batteries installed by us at the R.W. school at Onion Lake on or about the 5th of December 1931. I wish to make the following explanation:

Unfortunately for all concerned, those batteries were burnt up through overcharging and discharging. As mentioned to you, a set of batteries is only good for so many complete cycles and should not be relied upon for carrying all the load one may like them to do. The average life of a battery is from 3 to 10 hundred cycles. If you give that many cycles to a battery in a year's time they are used up. When we give the guarantee we do on a set of batteries we take it for granted that the owner is just as anxious to get the longest service possible out of his investment as we are to give him value for his money. Under the present circumstances, the owners relied upon employees and as a common occurrence in our days, the employees did not realize the extent of their responsibilities.

The batteries concerned started to give trouble last fall, and realizing the conditions, we done some work to them to try and extend the life for a while. We realized at the time that this was a gamble in the right way, but we lost out. They were too far gone at the time.

As stated verbally, we are willing to live up to our guarantee as per the attached form. This means that we agree to put in a complete new set of batteries for the sum of $362.50, which represents a service of two years, which we are charging for.
Sir,

I have the honour to report that the batteries at the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School are practically out of commission. They were purchased in December, 1931, by the Principal, Rev. Father Portier, from Blais Brothers Battery Co., Ltd., Edmonton. Recently, at the request of the new Principal, Rev. Father Pratt, I wrote the firm and they sent down Mr. L. D. Blais, who made an inspection, and his letter of the 26th ultimo, to me, which I am enclosing, describes their present condition, the terms on which they were purchased, also terms for replacement of batteries. At present it is necessary to keep the engine running when light is required, which is neither economical nor practical.

Awaiting your instructions.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Dear Dr. McGill:

We were more than pleased to welcome you on the occasion of your visit to our school and were complimented and encouraged by your sympathy and courtesy. During the short time you spent here you saw for yourself just how things were in the engine room. The children are now back and we fear very much that the 15 H.P Y Style Fairbanks Morse engine is about to fail us entirely.

It is completely played out, having received rough handling prior to my taking Office here and despite the patient and constant efforts of our qualified engineer, it is impossible to do anything more with it.

It is imperative therefore that the matter be dealt with at all possible speed, otherwise we are soon going to be without light, water and fire protection, and the cold weather will soon be here too.

If permission be granted, work can begin right away but in the mean time we absolutely must have the use of some kind of an engine to take the place of the one away being repaired.

We figure that the engine will be away at least two or three weeks. With regards also to engine which is used in case of fire, you agreed, if you remember to have it exchanged for a 20H.P. gas engine and furthermore you promised that if we wrote you later on the matter you would have Grant extended for the services of a Night-watchman from Oct. to March. Naturally after our past experience we dread fire very much.

Thanking you for your immediate attention in the matter of the defective engine

Dear Mr. McGill:

Mr. Blais from Edmonton just sent me a copy of the answer received from the Dept. concerning our new set of Batteries.

May I state that nothing was done without the consent of our local agent Dr. Hill.

When I took charge of this in February last, we were practically without any light and water supply. We were obliged to run constantly the big engine in order to keep the generator charging. As it was urgent that something be done immediately Dr. Hill our Indian Agent told me and Mr. Blais to go ahead and he will take up the question with the Dept.

Referring to your letter No. 115-8-6, dated October 3rd last, addressed to Hector T. Hill, Indian Agent, Onion Lake Agency, a copy of which was sent to me authorizing the expenditure of $900.00 for material and labour in erecting a new structure adjoining the engine room in the main building, repairing the 15 H.P. engine and the difference in connection with a proposed trade-in of the 25 H.P. engine.

I may advise you that immediately after the receipt of your letter I requested the Indian Agent to obtain an estimate of the cost of erecting the addition which he did and found that the cost of erecting the addition and repairing and installing the engine would exceed the amount allowed. Doctor Hill stated that the season was too far advanced to make a success of the cement work and he asked for my approval to move the present generator into the detached building with the 25 H.P. fire engine to generate the necessary light and power while the 15 H.P. engine was undergoing repairs. I at once got in touch with the Manager of the Fairbanks-Morse Company here and had an interview with him and their Manager from Winnipeg and explained the situation to them. They stated that the plan was feasible and I at once ordered the necessary cable, pulleys etc., to make the necessary hook up and had same shipped to the school.

I had planned to go to the school and telegraphed Doctor Hill to meet me at Lloydminster, but was unable to do so at that time owing to my wife's sudden and serious illness. I however visited the school on January 16th last and was surprised to find that nothing had been done since repairs were still unpacked. The 15 H.P. engine was knocking badly and four days later gave out entirely, leaving the school without light or pumping facilities in 45 degrees below zero weather. They appeared to be helpless with only half an inch of water showing in the gauge glass of the boiler. The Engineer over the telephone stated that he had no means of injecting water into the boiler other than the unit which was out of commission.

I advised that they use their farm tractor by making an opening in the wall of the building to admit the belt and erect a temporary shelter over the engine. This has been done and is working out alright. They have two heating boilers and they were told to shut off one and fill it with water by hand and when the water was exhausted in the one in operation, it could be shut off and the other fired and vice versa. This has met the emergency.

I instructed the Engineer to remove the 15 H.P. engine and prepare a base for the 25 H.P. engine and move it in. When this larger engine is installed it should meet their requirements for many years to come and it will not be necessary to provide the -
provide the proposed addition to the engine room. When the larger engine is installed the 15 H.P. engine can be repaired and installed in the outside pump house.

As there have been too many novices connected with the old engine, I am making arrangements with the Fairbanks-Morse Company to send a competent man to install the 25 H.P. engine properly.

I may say that the reason given by the Engineer for not installing the first proposed hook up with the fire engine was that the building in which it is installed is only a shell and it would be impossible to keep it warm enough in the extremely cold weather to prevent the cooling system from freezing up, and it has been impossible to operate this engine in winter for that reason.

Regarding the proposed trade in of the 25 H.P. engine on a 15 H.P., I found that I could get very little allowance for the larger engine although it has never been used. The reason being that so many villages and small towns find that they can purchase current from the large Power Companies cheaper than they can generate it themselves and there is no demand for that type of engine. In fact they can be purchased for a fraction of their value.

I trust that the Department will approve of the action I have taken. I have had in view providing an adequate unit to provide the requirements at the least possible cost.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,

Inspector's report on Onion Lake R/C Residential School

Sir:

I visited this school on January 18th and made a general inspection of the building, visited the classrooms, and made a general enquiry into conditions.

The Reverend Father Pratt is in charge as Principal. He is assisted by an adequate staff, including a Farming Instructor, Engineer, Night Watchman, and a staff of Sisters of Charity, three of whom are teachers. There are three classrooms. There are 110 pupils enrolled at the time of my visit, 55 boys and 60 girls. A grant is provided for 110, but I was informed that this is being increased to allow for 120 after the end of the present fiscal year.

The pupils presented a healthy appearance. I found the building very clean and tidy throughout. It is a large frame structure, heated by steam furnished by two large heating boilers. The school is electrically lighted. Water is piped through the building and pipes with hose connections on each floor are provided for fire protection as well as a supply of fire extinguishers placed at easily accessible points throughout the building. A lay-brother acts as night-watchman and makes hourly visits throughout the building during the night.

A separate fire-fighting unit was installed in an out-building. This unit consists of a 25 H.P. engine with a large rotary pump. This unit has never been operated. The building is not sufficiently warm to keep the water in the cooling system from freezing in extremely cold weather; and until proper housing is provided for this unit it will be useless to them.

While I was at this Agency the engine which operates the pumping and lighting plants gave out and temporary arrangements had to be made to carry on until such time as this engine could be repaired. It will be necessary to send the engine to Winnipeg in order to put it in shape, and in the meantime I instructed them to install the engine which has been used in the detached building. This work is now being carried out and the matter has been reported to the Department in a separate letter.

A farm is operated at this school and produced last year 600 bushels of wheat and 1000 bushels of oats. They grew about 25 tons of green feed. The garden and root crops were not up to the usual mark this season. They obtained only about 120 bushels of potatoes.

Their livestock includes 56 cattle, 10 work horses - 90 pigs and -

90 pigs and 65 poultry. They are milking 25 cows and have ample milk to allow the children all they care to drink. They purchased 65 tons of hay from the Indians to supplement the supply of green feed for the stock on the farm.

I may say that the exterior of the school building requires repainting very badly. The paint has sealed off the outside walls. Either a poor quality of paint was used in the first instance or it was put on too late in the season after the frost had set in. In any event the exterior of the school presents anything but a good appearance for this reason. The out-buildings are in a good state of repair and the premises are kept in a tidy condition.

REGINA, SASK., 29th April, 1935.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I am in receipt of copy of a letter dated March 25th addressed to yourself by the Reverend Father J. E. Pratt, Principal of the Onion Lake Roman Catholic Residential School, in which he reports in connection with their power unit, water supply, and hot water tank.

I may advise you that when I visited the school in January the weather was extremely cold. The Reverend Father did not at that time bring to my attention or make any complaint regarding the water supply itself or the condition at the spring. The serious problem at that time was obtaining power to operate their pumping unit and electric lighting plant. This was arranged for by moving the 25 H.P. engine which was provided to operate a pump in an outside building for fire protection and which could not be used. The 25 H.P. engine was placed in the school and is giving excellent satisfaction. The 15 H.P. engine requires very extensive repairs. The work of repairing this engine was held in abeyance until the other unit was installed.

They are however in exactly the same position with regard to exterior fire protection as they have been since the school was erected. The interior provision for fire protection consists of stand pipes installed in the building connected with pressure tanks and hose connections on each floor. It is a question in my mind if the rotary pump installed in the outside unit can ever be successfully operated. It appears to me to be too large and when an attempt has been made to operate it at full strength I am told that two men could not hold the hose. I have before me a report of the engineer, Mr. J. Littlewood, who goes very fully into the whole matter and his suggestion is that, if possible, the present

H. W. McGill, Esq., M.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
possible, the present rotary gear pump and old 15 H.P. engine be disposed of and a smaller unit installed. I feel very much inclined to agree with him. However as the summer is now approaching and it will be some months before there will be any real need for this unit, I would like to again visit the school and make a thorough enquiry into the whole business before submitting any further report or recommendation in connection with the matter. When I visited the school in January arrangements were made to meet the present emergency and that was done quite satisfactorily, but it was impossible during the winter months to take up any outside work.

Yours very truly,

Cher M. Sutherland,

Je viens de rencontrer le R.P. Pratt, principal de l'école de Onion Lake, et naturellement nous avons parlé du sujet dont je vous avais entretenu lors de mon récent passage à Ottawa, c'est-à-dire de la nécessité urgente de protéger l'école et ses habitants contre le feu.

Il m'a dit qu'il avait reçu la visite de l'Agent M. le Dr. Hill, et que tous deux avaient étudié ensemble de nouveau le projet sur lequel je vous ai laissé des notes et des estimations. L'exécution de ce projet entraînerait des dépenses un peu plus élevées que les $1,200 déjà votées pour la peinture de l'école. Je réitère cependant, auprès de vous et auprès du Surintendant Général, mes instances les plus pressantes pour que vous ne vous laissiez pas arrêter par ce surcroît de dépenses. Il me semble qu'il y a trop de dangers et trop peu de protection contre le feu pour qu'il soit permis d'hésiter. Je ne veux pas porter la responsabilité d'un tel état de choses lorsque la vie de tant d'enfants et d'un si nombreux personnel est en jeu; c'est pourquoi j'insiste avec tant de force pour que des mesures soient prises immédiatement.

Veuillez croire, cher M. Sutherland, à toute ma considération,

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I have just met the Rev. Father Pratt, Principal of the Onion Lake School, and, naturally, we spoke of that matter which I mentioned to you during my recent visit at Ottawa, that is to say, the urgent necessity of protecting the school and its inmates against fire.

He told me that he had received the visit of the Agent, Dr. Hall, and they studied together the new project about which I left you some estimates and dates. The execution of that project would cost a little more than the $1,200 already voted for the painting of the school. I reiterate, however, with you and with the Superintendent General, my most pressing instances so that you are not stopped by this little extra expense. It seems to me that there is too much danger and so little protection against fire to take any chance in hesitating. I do not wish to bear the responsibility of such a state of affairs, when the life of so many children and such a large staff is at stake; that is why I insist with so much energy so that the proper steps should be taken immediately.

I heard that the Department was to launch a building programme of a couple of hundred thousand dollars in the near future; I do not know what is true in this rumor. But if matters were at that stage, I could not help finding it strange to see the possibility of obtaining such considerable sums for a project which is not at all pressing, while you refuse the most urgent necessities to institutions which are already fully functioning.

Kindly believe, dear Mr. Sutherland, to all my consideration,

(Signed) U. Langlois, P. M. I.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 30th, with reference to the R.C. Indian Residential School.

The exterior of the building needs paint, but I agree that fire protection should be given precedence. This was provided in a way when the school was built. A 25 H.P. engine, with a six inch pump, was installed in a detached building for the purpose, but it never worked satisfactorily, as it required thirty minutes to get into action, and while in action it was almost impossible to handle the 3" hose. This particular engine was removed last spring to replace the 15 H.P. engine in the main building, where it is giving complete satisfaction; and the engine that was in the main building is not worth the freight to the factory, according to a representative of the firm of Fairbanks-Morse, who inspected it this week. He recommends a 75 H.P., Z type engine, with a 5000 G.P.M. pump, and two 1½ inch hose. The cost of this engine and pump, F.O.B., Lloydminster, together with accessories for installing, would be approximately $750.00. Two strings of 4½ inch hose, one hundred and fifty feet each, would cost 70¢ per foot.

The building in which the engine and pump were installed was built in a low spot, on a very low foundation. The foundation will have to be raised to prevent the surface water from running into the 20,000 gallon reservoir which is beneath the building. I would recommend that the above engine and pump be installed together with the 1½" hose, and that the foundation of the present building be raised at least one foot. The $1200.00 referred to should be sufficient, providing we get considerable assistance from the staff at the school.

Another item of importance is the hot water boiler at this school. It is corroded through at several points on the lower side and should be replaced. The boiler is 46" x 48" and costs at Crane Limited, Edmonton, $250.00. Freight and installation of this would be at least $100.00. I regret the delay in forwarding this reply, as it was most difficult to get the information that I am conveying. The Rev. Principal of the School wanted a frost-proof building, 30x60, with a garage at one end for four cars. The building alone would have cost $1200.00. I tried to get a price on the six inch pump, but Fairbanks-Morse would not make an offer but promised to notify us when they had a sale for it. I also expected that the old engine would have been worth something on a trade-in. The pool formed by the spring should be cleaned out and enlarged; and it is quite evident that all of the $1200.00 will be...
will be utilized for the water and fire protection, and no portion of it will be available for the replacing of the hot water boiler.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. McGill:

I must thank you very sincerely for the good will shown to this school by allowing us to spend the money $1000.00 voted for the painting of this school towards the equipment of fire protection.

This gesture from your part is well appreciated here and by the Staff and by the authority of our Church.

I have been talking with our Local Indian Agent Dr. Hill about it and also had the Fairbanks Morse people at the school to look at the things. Those people are not ready to give anything for the big Fire Protection Pump and hose and any fire protection whatever against fire except the inside fire house. This big gump is too big for this school and its capacity is strong enough to supply II or two hydrants and will be the thing for a large city or a school were there is an unlimited amount of water.

You saw by yourself Dear Mr. McGill during your visit last Summer how things are here at the school and we are at the very same point.

Last Winter our 15 H.P. Engin broke down entirely and we with your permission have bought in the 25H.P. Engin which gives entire satisfaction.

I would like to start the work on the proposed building over the water supply or reservoirs immediately and also to install the other engine. Dr. Hill is getting full information from the Fairbanks Morse Co. and also the definite statement about what is urgently required here.

The Spring, our main water supply needs badly to be cleaned and I have been asking it to Dr. Hill our Agent for quite a while and I suppose he intends to include it in his visitation. The water needs to be analysed as the children were sick last Winter and we are inclined to believe that the water must be for something in it.

Our boiler tank I mean our Hot Boiler tank is badly leaking and has been plugged with a wooden plug and also needs to be repleased as it is entirely gone out with rust. I fear very much to start the winter with the hot boiler in such a state. What will we do during the cold spell she breaks entirely. We could in no way keep the house and everything will freeze solid. It is quite a job to remove this boiler and install a new one as the house has been built to meet such an emergency.

Dear Mr. McGill it is my greatest desire to have the work called for done immediately as we are very busy by now and we will be more busy yet when teaching comes. It is getting late already and Rev. Father Langlois our Head Superior has sent me a brother carpenter to do the work on those buildings in order to save money and time and I am still waiting for the definite answer from the Dept. through the local Indian Agency. Please allow us to start at least the building over the reservoirs and to clean the Spring down below the Hill before the children come back.

Again I repeat I am very grateful to you and to the Dept. for what they have already allowed us and we sure deeply appreciate it.

Wishing Dear Mr. McGill that you will understand my position and the reasons for rushing the work.

I remain

Yours very truly

Rev. Fr. J.E. Battison
Principal
St Anthony's school, Lloydminster, Sask.

Hot Water Tank

The tank that supplies the Hot Water for the school started to leak on February the 24th 1935. This leak has been repaired in a temporary manner, and the hot water supply has been maintained up to the present.

The cause of the leak is due to corrosion of the metal by the alkali in the water. On examination, the tank shows evidence of having several weak places along the lower portion where the water lies, and it is certain that it will not last much longer, also that it would be more costly to keep in repair than it would to install a new tank. We have experience of some other tanks that have started to corrode in this manner and the most economical thing to do is to replace them with new ones at once, as trying to repair them has proved to be most unsatisfactory.

Report on Fire Equipment Water Supply

The water for the use of the school, for drinking, domestic supply and fire appliances is taken from a spring, approximately 100 yards from the school.

Beside the pool formed by the spring is a pump house and a reservoir which is 8-0 by 800 feet deep. This reservoir is filled from the pool by a ½" pipe and takes about 5 hrs. to fill. The pump has a 2½" discharge and its capacity is 2000 gallons per hour; it is driven by a 6 H.P. Fairbanks Morse Engine. The water is pumped from here to another reservoir at the Fire Pump House near the School Buildings. The reservoir here is 20 by 12-0 by 10-0 deep. The capacity of the reservoir is about 4000 gallons and the capacity of the reservoir at the school is about 18000 gallons.

The pump at the spring can empty the reservoir there in about 2 hours and it takes 15 hours to fill up again and in its present condition cannot keep up a sufficient supply for fire purposes.

We would suggest that the pool formed by the spring should be cleaned out and enlarged and that the reservoir for the pump should be supplied by a 4" pipe so as to keep a sufficient supply of water to keep the pump running independently; this could be done with...
Fire Pump House:

This was equipped with a 25 H.P. Fairbanks Morse Engine and a 6" Rotary Gear Pump which was capable of emptying the reservoir in about half an hour, after which the water supply was finished. This plant was contained in a pump house built partly over the reservoir and with no concrete foundation, consequently all the surface water from round about is drained into the reservoir and as this water is used for drinking and is the only supply the result is far from satisfactory.

The 25 H.P. Engine has been removed and taken to replace the 15 H.P. Engine to drive the Generator for the lighting supply and also the Laundry machinery, the 15 H.P. Engine that was used for this purpose being in such a condition that it would cost more to recondition it than it is worth.

The Rotary Gear Fire Pump has a 6" suction Pipe and one 3" Fire Hose is taken of the discharge side the remainder of the discharge is returned to the reservoir through a 6" eye pass pipe so that at per cent of the energy taken to drive this pump is wasted in the 6" eye pass pipe.

We suggest that this pump be disposed of and in its place there should be installed a pump of similar pattern as is used in the pump house at the spring; so a 2000 gallon per pump with a 2½" fire house discharge driven by a 6"H.P. Engine of Fairbanks Morse Z Type. The advantage of this is that the Engine can be started up at a moment's notice in cold weather; the cooling water hopper would be empty and no fear of the Engine or pump freezing both being drained. All that would be necessary to start up would be to run over with a pail of hot water, pour it in the Engine Hopper and start up which could be done in one minute; previously it took at least 35 minutes to start up the 25 H.P. Engine for the Fire Pump. We would also suggest that the new engine & pump should be direct coupled and not Belt driven.

There should be a new building to contain the Fire Equipment which should be kept heated in winter and used also as a Motor Garage, this building should be over the Fire Reservoir and built on a concrete foundation. The concrete walls of the reservoir should be brought up to above ground level to prevent surface water entering the drinking water. We have an estimate for the purpose new building and we think the other improvements...
would not cost more than about $900.00 dollars this without the proposed new building.

If the Rotary Gear Pump and the old 15 H.P. Engine could be disposed of advantageously the receipts from the sale of these two items would go a long way towards the expense of the new Equipment and improvements.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that I visited the St. Anthony's R/C Indian Residential School in the Onion Lake Agency on the 3rd instant accompanied by Indian Agent, Doctor Hill, and made a general inspection of the institution. We had a special invitation to meet several dignitaries of the Church; including the Superior General of the Oblate Order from Rome, Bishop Breynet of the Mackenzie district, Bishop Prudhomme of Prince Albert, Father Langlois of Edmonton, the Reverend Mother General of the Order of Sisters of the Assumption from Nicolet, Quebec, and several Priests from the two Provinces.

The pupils were assembled in their three classrooms which I visited accompanied by Bishop Prudhomme and the Mother General. The children presented a healthy and well nourished appearance. They responded brightly to questions asked them and made a very favorable impression. There are 117 pupils enrolled, 54 boys and 63 girls.

A general inspection of the building was made. It presented a well kept and tidy appearance. The exterior walls of the building are badly sealed. The paint has come off to a large extent and something will have to be done. The paint job on this building has been very unsatisfactory. The paint started to scale off shortly after the work was done and before the walls can be repainted they will have to be scraped, which will entail a lot of extra work and expense. I am of the opinion that it might be more economical in the end to place a cement stucco on the outside walls rather than to repaint them. A cement stucco would add to the warmth of the -

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
warmth of the building and effect a saving in fuel. Before undertaking to repaint this building, I would suggest that the question of the cost of stucco as compared with the cost of paint be ascertained, and, if the difference in cost is not too great, I feel that it might be good business to use stucco.

A new hot water boiler was on hand, but had not yet been installed.

The equipment to provide an independent unit for fire protection has been ordered for some time, but had not been delivered at the time of my visit.

The 25 H.P. engine which was transferred from the pump house to the school building is giving very satisfactory service.

The source of water supply at the spring was examined. The intake drain to the reservoir will be cleaned out and filled with coarse gravel which should insure a steady supply of pure water.

Since my visit in January last a new engineer has been engaged. He impressed me as being a capable man. The equipment under his care is being kept in good working order and its appearance indicates that it is receiving proper attention.

Farm: The farm crop this year at the school consisted of 30 acres of wheat, 60 acres of oats, 25 acres of barley, and 20 acres of green feed. They threshed 425 bus. of wheat, 2650 bus. of oats, 900 bus. of barley, and harvested 400 bus. of potatoes as well as some garden produce. The quality of the grain was affected by early frosts.

The live stock consists of 10 work horses, 3 colts, 20 milk cows, 50 other cattle, 120 pigs, and 140 poultry. Three hundred tons of hay have been put up for the farm stock.

The above report is respectfully submitted.

Your obedient servant,

W. Muriel,

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that, owing to the break-down of the pump engine at the School, we are under serious difficulties owing to the hold-up of our water supply.

The base frame of the pump engine was broken last winter and I had it welded after going to considerable trouble and expense to dismount it and take it to Lloydminster. The weld, however, did not hold for any length of time and the situation became so bad that I had to take it to Lloydminster for the second time. This time the weld did not hold for more than two minutes, and the engine is now in such condition that I dare not run it and am, therefore, held up.

I have obtained a price from the Fairbanks-Morse Company on a new frame for this engine and it would cost $135.57 laid down in Lloydminster. In addition there would be an expense of approximately $5.00 for repairing other small breakages caused by this break-down.

I have taken this matter up with Dr. Hill, the Indian Agent at Onion Lake, and he agrees with me that there is only one thing to do and that is to buy a new base for this engine, and has intimated that he will write to you also on this matter.

The purpose of this letter is, therefore, to request that you give me authority to spend up to $140.00 for these repairs. I wish to point out to you that this is a real emergency with the winter coming on, and would be very grateful to you if you would look into this matter and give me the necessary authority with the least possible delay.

With very pleasant remembrances of your last visit to the School, I am, dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

St. Anthony's School
per [Signature]
Principal

Nov. 30th, 1935

Mr. W.H. Hill,
Deputy Sup't. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I wish to thank you for your letter of the 14th inst., in which you advise me that the Indian Agent at Onion Lake, Dr. Hill, has been instructed to purchase an Acetylene Welding Outfit for our school. This will be a big help to us, and I wish to assure you that I appreciate this authority very much.

I wish to take up with you two matters in reference to our school work, on which I would like your consideration:

First: due to the fact that we are now handling 120 children instead of 110 for which we are equipped, we are short of desks for the lower grade and also room in which to handle the children of this grade. This matter was taken up with Mr. Morrison when he visited the School, and he approved of another room in which these children could be taught and took with him a list of the desks needed but, to date, we have not heard anything from your Department in reference to this matter.

Secondly, I would like to get your permission to receive into the School seven children from the LeGoff and Cold Lake Reserves. Two of these children belong to the Desjardins family, of which we have already been given permission to receive two children. The other five belong to the Desjarlais family. While these children are all half-breeds, their mothers are pure Indian and they are all living on the Reserve, the Desjarlais children and their mother living with their Grandparents who are Treaty Indians, and, as there are no public schools anywhere near these reserves, this is the only opportunity the children have of receiving an education. I would, therefore, appreciate it very much if you would forward the necessary authority for us to receive these children.

I hope that you will take both these matters into consideration and let me know your decision as soon as possible. Thanking you in advance, I am

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal
ST. ANTHONY'S SCHOOL

Dear Sir:

We regret to inform you that we have received a complaint from the Principal of the R.C. Indian School at Onion Lake in regard to the trouble they had with their batteries again.

He has sent us two of the jars, and upon examining same, we find that the positive plates are worn out. This does not surprise us, as we are aware of the fact that the present lighting plant installation at that school is exacting too much from any set of batteries.

As already explained to Dr. Hill and Father Pratt, the charging system is not the proper one to give fair treatment to a set of storage batteries.

First, the fact of charging those batteries in two banks is very obsolete, especially with the lead that they have to carry in this case. The result of the above conditions is that when the generator is running, they are liable to be overcharged, and when the engine is not running, the lead is too heavy.

As you are aware, a set of storage batteries are only able to give so many cycles, and when these cycles have taken place, they have done their duty and no one can expect more from them. In the present case, the cycle capacity is between four hundred and four hundred and fifty.

We might recall that when we installed the first set in 1932, we mentioned at the time that, had we known the type of installation existing at that school, we would never have agreed to give the usual guarantee. However, the batteries were there and such an attitude on our part might have been taken as if we wanted to dodge our responsibility as a reliable firm. This we refused to do, and it turned out to be expensive for us.

It is not our intention to dictate to the Department what to do or not to do. We simply want to make our position clear and emphasize the fact that it is impossible and useless as well to carry on replacing these batteries, even under our adjustment basis guarantee, with the present system existing.

Trying to do this, we consider would be unfair, both to us and the Department.
May we be permitted also to call your attention to the fact that the water pump alone is quite a load on the batteries, and no one can expect the 25 horse power engine to run for that purpose alone.

The Principal of the School does not want to take upon himself any more responsibility in this, without the authorization from the Department. On the other hand, there is a danger of being without light or water at any time.

When we consider that there is over a hundred lives at stake if that should happen, miles away from any outside help, we are arranging immediately to relieve their situation.

Again, we wish to repeat what we have already said, namely that we are not trying to dictate, but as citizens and in fairness to all concerned, we consider some changes should be done with the present electrical installation.

Yours respectfully

Dear Dr. McGill:

I regret very much to have to inform you that the Lighting Plant in our school is giving me considerable trouble, and it has now got to the stage where batteries are almost useless. In fact, the present state of the batteries is such that we have to run the 25 H.P. Engine all the time that we need light, even during the short periods in which we have to turn off our water pump. This means, of course, that, as storage batteries, they are absolutely useless.

There are two very serious consequences to this state of affairs. One is that the cost is almost prohibitive as we used 793 gallons of fuel and a complete barrel of lubricating oil during the month of December, and it is quite possible that the quantity will be even larger for January. In addition to this there is the expense of coal oil lamps which we are compelled to use during the main part of the night when the plant is not running.

There is also what might be considered a much more serious side to this state of affairs, and that is the danger of coal collapse in a wooden school housing 120 children, to say nothing of the staff.

As you know, this plant has been declared inadequate by several engineers who know their business and, from all the information we can obtain, this appears to be the reason for the batteries giving out in less than half of their natural life. These experts tell us that the plant is not only inadequate to carry the load but that the system under which the charging is done also damages the plates.

These, however, are technical questions which I am not fully qualified to discuss, and I would suggest that sometime when it is convenient to your Dept. you would have a qualified engineer pass on the ability of this plant to do the work required of it.

I would further like to point out that I have taken special care to see that a duly qualified man is in charge of the plant, the man in charge having taken special courses in the operation of both Diesel engines and electric light plants. When this man took over the plant after looking it over he informed me that while he would do his best, he certainly would not like to take full responsibility for the plant giving satisfaction as it was overloaded and the batteries were not suitable.

This, however, is beside the point at the present time as the matter of vital importance right now is just what to do to give us light for the balance of the winter, and the situation is gradually getting worse. I find that I can obtain from the people from whom the batteries were bought new groups of plates and material necessary to repair these batteries for $150.00 In addition to this I could have to buy sufficient acid to bring them all up to strength, the cost of which I do not know. Also there would be, ordinarily, an extra charge for a man and his expenses to install these materials. The last time this was done it cost me approximately $75.00. This, however, could be saved in the present instance as the man I have in charge is willing and capable of going this far.

Having explained this matter to you as fully as I can I would request that you give me authority to spend this $150.00 for material and as much more as will be necessary for acid, and freight, so that the plant may be put into shape to continue until next summer or such time as you see your way to have a competent engineer to examine the plant and make you a report. This matter is very pressing and I hope that you will
give it your immediate and favorable attention

Thanking you in anticipation, and hoping to hear from you by return, I am

Yours very truly

ST. ANTHONY'S SCHOOL

Sir,

I am in receipt of your 115-8-5, of the 4th instant, with reference to the batteries for use in connection with the lighting plant at the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, and in reply.

The school supply of water is procured from a lake, approximately 500 yards distant. At this point there is an installation, engine and pump, which forces the water up a steep hill into a large reservoir located about thirty feet from the main building. The reservoir supplies the water tank in the school by means of a small electric motor which works automatically. This is the only part that has been made of the batteries, apart from lighting the buildings, and apparently it was the intention when the building was constructed, as it is part of the original installation.

However, I conveyed the Department's instructions to the Principal and the engineer, and both agreed to comply, but it will mean the running of the 25 H.P. engine twice daily to get sufficient water in the storage tanks. This in turn is hard on the engine and expensive to the school, e.g., it took 793 gallons of crude oil to operate the plant in December. My knowledge of batteries is very limited but from the information I have been able to gather, together with some comments in Blais Brother's letter, it would appear that the original installation, which is known as the two pole and double switch board system, is not the most suitable. Blais Brothers' opinion is that it is very obsolete, due, I believe, to the faulty distribution in the cells. The fact remains that two sets of batteries have been completely used up since 1932 in this school, and they are practically without electric light. The secondary system, lamps, is being partially used. The Principal now requests plates and materials to repair the batteries, which can be purchased for $10.00 from Blais Brothers, Edmonton. His electrician is quite capable to carry out the repairs. I regret that I do not know sufficient about batteries and lighting systems to make a definite recommendation. The Principal's request if conceded will restore the batteries for a time, but it may probably be more economical to install a more modern system that would give less trouble and some degree of satisfaction. The present batteries consist of 36 cells.

I have the honour to be,

Sir

Dear Sir:

I wish to express my appreciation and thanks for the permission contained in your letter of February 4th to spend $160.00 repairing the storage batteries at the school. The "Brother" I have at the School and who is a qualified engineer, is repairing the batteries free of charge and seems to think that, with these repairs, the batteries should be in shape to carry us through the School Year.

I understand from Dr. J.T. Hill, the Indian Agent, that he recommended that the system be changed if possible before next winter and be brought up to date as he realizes that if this is not done there will never be 100% satisfaction and will always be more expensive to keep up as brand new batteries have never, at any time, lasted more than 2½ years.

From your letter I gather that you have a certain misunderstanding in reference to this system, as you seem to think that the storage batteries are being used for other purposes than for which they were intended when installed. I would like to explain, in reference to this, that the system has never been changed since it was installed, the hook-up for water, etc., being exactly the same as when it was new. In reference to pumping the water, which you seem to think causes this damage, I would like to point out that the water is originally pumped from the spring into a storage tank by a 6 H.P gas engine and is pumped from the storage tank into the basement tanks by an electric motor which starts and stops automatically. This pumping by the electric motor takes place three times a day, morning noon, and night evening. In the morning and in the evening this motor is run when the generator is running and takes the current direct from the generator, and it is only for about half an hour in the middle of the day that it draws from the storage batteries and at that time it only draws approximately 10 amps. for the half hour it runs, so you will see that the charge or suggestion made that the batteries are being used to pump the water for the School thereby causing too large a drain on them, is not correct.

I wish also to assure you that, in addition to there being no change made, every care is being taken by a qualified man to do everything possible to save an excessive draw on the power of the batteries. I felt, in view of certain remarks in your letter, that it would be as well to explain this matter to you.

Again thanking you for your courtesy and past favor.

I am

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
