MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Referring to the postscript to the letter from His Lordship Bishop Prudhomme, of Prince Albert, requesting that the main school building at the St. Anthony's Indian Residential School, Onion Lake, Sask., be brick veneered and stuccoed, in order to overcome fire hazard, I would state as follows:

The Architect informs me that the present foundation of the building would not carry the weight of brick veneering the exterior of the building. An estimate has been received of the cost of stuccoing the entire building, for the sum of $5,826.00.

This is a three-storey frame building. Either brick veneering or stuccoing the exterior of the building would not overcome fire hazard, as there is little danger of fire from outside sources. Fires are more likely to occur inside the building. Last year, a large expenditure was incurred in placing the water supply system for fire protection purposes in good condition.

good condition. No funds have been provided to either brick veneer or stucco the building.

The Anglican Indian Residential School at Onion Lake is a building of similar type, and, if the Catholic school was brick veneered, the Anglican authorities would, no doubt, request that similar work be carried out at their school.

It is considered if the exterior of the St. Anthony's Catholic School is painted, this should be satisfactory and greatly improve the appearance of the building. Funds for this purpose could be included in our Estimates for the coming fiscal year. It would cost approximately $1,600.00 to paint the exterior of the building.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General:-

I have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the first instant, requesting information regarding the Onion Lake R.C. (St. Anthony's) and the Onion Lake Church of England Indian Residential Schools.

The Department owns both these schools. The St. Anthony's (R.C.) School was erected during the fiscal year 1927-28. The Church of England School was erected during the fiscal year 1925-26.

These schools are located on reserves, and the Church Authorities did not possess ownership in the buildings that were in use previous to the erection of the new schools.

Attached hereto are statements, showing the total cost of buildings and the furnishings, equipment, and repairs carried out during each fiscal year since these schools were erected.

No painting has been done to the exterior of the St. Anthony's (R.C.) School since the building was erected. Funds were provided to have the exterior of the school painted in the summer of 1936, but the Principal of the School and the Church Authorities requested that the funds be utilized, instead, in repairing water and fire protection services.

The exterior of the Church of England School building and the outbuildings were painted during the summer of 1930 and in the summer of 1935.

Re--Painting

Dear Sir:—

I am pleased to note that the estimates for St. Anthony's School presented to the Dept. by Bishop Guy have received approval.

There is one matter however that I feel I ought in fairness to the Dept to bring to your attention.

Owing to a very poor paint job originally the outside of the School building is in very poor condition and considerable expense will be necessary to put it in shape for new paint as each board will have to be scraped separately.

This being the case I would suggest that the Dept consider the advisibility of putting Stucco on the building and so make a permanent job that would save considerable expense in the future.

I hope that you will regard this suggestion favorably, and will let me know what you think of it.

With sincere thanks for past kindness

Yours sincerely,

ST. ANTHONY'S SCHOOL

File--E..7
Sir,

I have the honour to refer to the condition of the exterior of the R.C. Indian Residential School. Something should be done to it this year if finances will permit.

The original painting was faulty, owing, I believe, to most of the work being done very late in the season, when it was subjected to frost. The boards are showing through, and in places 50% of the paint is entirely gone, and that remaining resembles fish scales. In its present state it will take considerable labour to prepare the surface for paint, and, under the circumstances, perhaps stucco should be considered. The work involved in preparing the surface would be at least three times as much as that required for the actual painting.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J.T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honour to report the following incident in connection with the R. C. Indian Residential School. On the 12th instant smoke, which could not be accounted for, was discovered in a hall in the basement. After considerable investigating it was finally located in the interior of the wall, a small portion of which was removed and a fire extinguished. A defective wire connecting the fire alarm bell with the electric system had ignited the lath upon which it was resting. The repair should be made at once as it is important the fire alarm system be intact at all times, but in order to do this in its present location I am told that a considerable portion of the wall would have to be torn down. An alternative, which I would recommend, would be to make the connection on the outside of the wall, and, in this event, the enclosed list, which was made at my request, by the resident engineer and electrician at the school, would be required.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-8-5, of the 5th instant, with reference to painting the exterior of the R.C. Indian Residential School.

An estimate of the cost of material required, submitted by the Sterling Millwork Co., North Battleford, is $490.45, as follows:

For Walls, and Verandah Ceilings, $387.15
" Roof, (tarred, shingled and galvanized) $103.30

George Blower, a local painter who has been doing the Agency work for many years, offers to contract the work at $500.00. The work to consist of wire brushing the walls and applying two coats of paint. The original painting was done late in the season and was damaged by frost, and the surface of the building, especially the east side, resembles inverted fish scales. The work in connection with removing these and preparing the surface for paint will require much more time than that for applying the paint. Blower's estimate may appear high, but in view of the condition of the building and the preparation required, I think it fairly reasonable. His services are also available at 45¢ per hour. The work, if funds will permit, should be proceeded with at once as the exterior of the building is in a very bad state of preservation.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-8-5, of July 6th, 1937, re J. E. Gagnon's account with the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School.

I could not get any definite information in connection with the case until today, as the Reverend Father Pratt, who was principal when Gagnon joined the staff, was transferred on May 20th, and his successor, Rev. Father Pascal, knew nothing of the arrangements between Father Pratt and Mr. Gagnon.

Today I succeeded in getting a history of the case from the lay brother, who is the chief executive in the absence of the principal, and has been on the staff for several years. He states that J. E. Gagnon, his wife and son, arrived at the school in September or October, 1935, and asked to be taken on the staff for their keep as they were unemployed. They were admitted on compassionate grounds but were not assigned any special duties as they were to make themselves generally useful. During the seven month interval between May 1st and December, the following year, he was promised and received $20.00 per month wages for six months, from the school, and $100.00 from the Department, for interior painting in the R. C. School. The brother claims that Father Pratt paid him in full before he left and that Father Pascal paid him an additional $50.00 before he returned him on the flat. The last $50.00 was not due him, but he just gave it to him as a peace offering - as all agreements between Father Pratt and Gagnon had been verbal. Gagnon was a first class painter and did a most satisfactory job in the school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 30th instant enclosing requisition from the principal of Onion Lake R.C. Residential School for a new set of batteries.

G.Da12 .66 cells, 110, Volt.168.A. H. GLOBELITE Battery.

The principal also states in his letter that he has secured a price on the Globalite batteries F.O.B. Frenchman's Butte. Please let me know why he mentions this place, as we have always understood that the freight address of this school is Lloydminster, Saskatchewan.

Onion Lake, Sask.
Dear Sir,

Owing to the great distance from town or railway centres & necessarily much more expenses are occasioned by freight etc., thus am obliged today to ask the Department for further help with the supply of paint for the farm buildings; four dormitories of the Main Building have been left unpainted for lack of paint last year. More over two sewing machines would also be greatly appreciated as the old ones now refuse service.

I had to buy a new binder last fall to take in the crop; to replace the engines of the pump house.

For fire protection I had to install the tank for the gas under ground and thus get rid ourselves from the dangerous barrels around the buildings.

Owing to all these expenses I would like to be favoured with a certain amount to help defraying and it seems to me that about $1000 would not be too much to meet with the expenses made.

Your cooperation would be greatly appreciated.

Thanking you in advance I remain,

Truly yours,

[Signature]

Principal.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo requesting paint and two sewing machines for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

In preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year, it was found possible to include an amount of $600 only for repairs, improvements, and purchase of material at the Onion Lake R.C. School.

Today we received a letter from the Indian Agent, Dr. Hill, in which he states that a new set of batteries is required by your school. We have been obliged to write him for further information. However, these batteries will cost approximately $400. In this event, it would mean that there would be $200 remaining for the purchase of other equipment for the school. However, the Department does not wish to make any further expenditures at Onion Lake R.C. School until the batteries are secured and we are certain of their cost. You might discuss your requirements with Dr. Hill and he will let you know what amount is available after the batteries have been secured. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to him.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division

Frenchman's Butte being twelve miles nearer the School than Lloydminster was the reason given by the Principal for having them shipped to this point. I interviewed the Principal and he will be quite pleased with a standard set of any make.

I have the honour to be,

MEMORANDUM

19th April, 1927.

Dr. Scott,

Will you kindly let me know if your Department propose employing building inspectors this summer in connection with the erection of Indian buildings at Onion Lake and at Ramsack, Saskatchewan.

Mr. Rod. Grant, who was employed last year as Inspector at Sturgeon Landing is anxious to be re-employed. Could he be employed on either one of these new schools without the new positions being advertised by the Civil Service Commission?

[Signature]

Private Secretary.
Memorandum,

April 23, 1927.

Mr. Pratt,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your memorandum of the 19th instant, and to say in reply that we have in the Estimates for the present fiscal year items to cover the cost of erecting two Roman Catholic schools, one at the Onion Lake agency and the other at the Keesee-koose reserve, in the Felly agency, but we are not, as yet, in a position to employ an Inspector of Construction. We received an application from Mr. Roderick Grant for appointment as Inspector of Construction during the coming summer and we have simply acknowledged it, but have made a note of his desire to be re-employed and will keep his name in view. On inquiry from the Civil Service Commission I learn that they have an eligible list but that the first name appearing on it is that of Mr. Hamilton, the second Mr. Roderick Grant. It is possible that Mr. Hamilton may not be available and that there will be no difficulty in engaging Mr. Grant when the time comes.

Deputy Superintendent General.

I beg to advise you that you have been appointed Inspector of Construction for the proposed new Union Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, and you will be paid at the rate of $6.00 per day for your services. Kindly report at once to Indian Agent Long Turner, Union Lake, Sask., who will give you the necessary particulars as to the location of this building. The contract has been awarded to Messrs. Brown and Lindsay, 791 Weston Ave., Winnipeg, Man., at their tendered price of $479,691.00. You will be expected to devote all of your time to this work, and to take particular care to see that the building is erected in strict accordance with the plans and specifications. I would particularly ask you to make sure that the lumber used in the construction of this building is well seasoned. I would also draw your attention to the fact that under no circumstances will the Department pay for any extra work performed in connection with this contract unless same has been authorized in writing by the Department, and this should be strongly impressed on the contractors when the work is commenced.

I am sending you, under separate cover, certificate forms, which should be issued in favour of the contractor when money is due on his contract. These should be forwarded to the Department in duplicate. I am also sending you diary sheets which should be kept by you and at the end of each month handed to Indian Agent Turner, who will forward a voucher to the Department for payment of your services. I would ask you to kindly submit a fortnightly report covering the progress of the work.

A copy of the plans and specifications are being sent you, care of the Indian Agent.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:
Re Onion Lake Indian Agency and Roman Catholic Indian Residential School.

While Mr. Cornish was at Onion Lake recently inspecting the Church of England School he made a survey of the Agency building area, the plan of which will be available if the Department should re-open the matter of supplying light to the various buildings. A spring, suitable for a water supply, was also located.

An inspection was also made of the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School. The sewage disposal system was found to be in poor condition but the Principal will have the septic tank cleaned out and certain repairs effected which should put it in good working order.

Dear Rev. Plourde:

The writer called at the St. Anthony Indian School in October last year, and had quite a nice visit with Father Pascal. A representative of our firm usually calls at this school every year. We do this usually to inspect the lighting unit, particularly the battery, because most of the installations are Globelite batteries and, as part of our service, we endeavour to contact every school and agency.

The installation in the St. Anthony School is a 180 A.H. battery which will have to be replaced probably in the next six months. In conversation with Father Pascal and the Engineer, they acknowledged that the battery was far too small for the load it has to carry. A larger capacity battery would be far more serviceable, efficient and more economical to operate, and they are therefore interested in our type W15, 315 A.H. battery, or our type W17, 360 A.H. battery. One of the latter is installed in the School at Delmas where it is giving excellent satisfaction.

When it comes time to replace the present battery at the St. Anthony School, we would like to know will it be bought locally by Father Pascal or will your department handle the transaction, or will it go through the Department of Indian Affairs who purchased most of the batteries in the Indian Schools. If you will be good enough to give us this information, it will be very much appreciated and we will then know to whom we will submit a quotation and make the necessary recommendations about the size and capacity.

The writer contacted Mr. Leveille, Mr. Allen and The Canadian Publishers Limited, who are well known to the writer, and we have enjoyed very satisfactory business relations for some years. They of course gave me your address which has prompted this letter.

Yours truly,

GLOBELITE BATTERIES LIMITED.

Sales Manager.

Mr. Donald Cameron,

Onion Lake, Sask.

Dear Sir:

May I draw the attention of the Department upon the necessity of having the frame of our temporary root cellar built about nine years ago by the school, renewed completely, owing to the fact that the roof and walls are caving in.

We consulted Mr. Guy Hunter and we received a complete plan and evaluation on the subject. It would have concrete walls and a new roof with a capacity of approximately 3,000 bushels of potatoes, including material and labour the price would amount to no more than three hundred dollars.

The school will furnish the gravel and hauling of cement and lumber along with some rough help for the cement mixing.

We should greatly appreciate a prompt reply from the Department in order to start this urgent work immediately after sowing.

I trust that you will approve our request.

Devotedly yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

St. Anthony School,
via Lloydminster, Sask.

I enclose herewith a letter received from the Principal of the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School reporting on the condition of the root cellar and requesting an expenditure of not more than $300.00 to have it repaired and improved.

It is in real bad shape this spring and should be completely re-built using concrete walls. I would strongly recommend that this expenditure be allowed.

Reference your letter 115-8-5 (WT1) dated 25 Sept:

It is my understanding that when Mr Cameron first took up the question of repairs to the engine at Onion Lake R.C. School, the cost of the crank shaft was approx $500.00 and the installation charges would cost approx $20.00 per day, and on this basis the Principal was advised to proceed with the repairs.

To date the engine has not been overhauled, and the repairs have not been carried out.

About a month ago I spoke to the new Principal, who informed me that he was having difficulty in this connection, and that the Cor had advised him that a new crank shaft and installation would be in the neighbourood of $1000.00. He stated that from his experience with this particular engine over a period of years, that the general condition of the machine was very bad, and that even if it were possible to have the authorised repairs done, the engine performance would be far from satisfactory, and a new engine in the long run would be more economical.

I pointed out that authority had been obtained for repairs only, but that if in his opinion a new engine was necessary, he should immediately make application through the Agency Office to this effect, and submit his reasons for the new request, together with comparative costs etc; in order that I could take the matter up with the Dept.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Onion Lake, R.C. Residential School.

With reference to your memorandum of January 19th last, in connection with electrical equipment for the above schools, you are advised that three tenders were received by the Departmental Purchasing Agent in response to requests for quotations from Western Firms for equipment as specified by the Indian Affairs Branch. These tenders were referred to this Division for advice as to the suitability of equipment offered.

According to information on file, the existing lighting plants are composed of the following equipment:

(a) Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.
   10 K.W. generator driven by a 25 horsepower diesel engine charging a 316 ampere hour 110 volt storage battery.

(b) Guy Residential School.
   7.5 K.W., 125 to 180 volts D.C. generator driven by a 16 horsepower steam engine charging a 220 ampere hour 110 volt storage battery.

We note from the call for quotations, only one diesel electric unit is required and that two schools are under consideration, and it is assumed that an investigation has been made at both locations and generating equipment at present in use was found to be worn out and requires replacing.

There are many different types of systems available for operation from storage batteries and in order to select the proper generating equipment it is necessary to have all the facts concerning the electrical system before attempting to choose a generator and controls applicable to the existing conditions. We do not have this information on our file and we are therefore, not in a position to advise if the equipment offered is suitable for use at the schools under consideration.

We suggest that the Indian Affairs Branch defer the placing of orders based on tenders received until further information can be obtained. If Indian Affairs concur in this action we would ask them to obtain the following information from both schools and upon receipt of same this Division will give it prompt consideration.

1. A detailed description of the generator now in use including all available information regarding watts capacity, voltage, speed and type of winding. Nameplates are usually furnished on the generator giving this information.

2. Describe in detail the control panel listing all equipment and describe exactly how the prime mover is controlled i.e. whether automatic relay electric start, manual push button electric start or by some other method.

3. Have the controls given any trouble in the past and if so state fully and give dates? Are the controls now operating satisfactorily?

Encs.

Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Lighting Plant Equipment - Onion Lake Residential School, Sask.

With reference to your memorandum of April 29th enclosing four tenders in connection with the above and your further memorandum of May 5th with detailed specification of tender from Medland Machinery Limited of Winnipeg, we have reviewed the tenders submitted and make the following comments:

Three firms submitted detailed specifications of equipment offered as requested in the Call for Tenders, the fourth firm, namely Electric Equipment Limited of Saskatoon, did not include detailed information of equipment offered. The tenders submitted by this firm quoted on battery charging equipment and the Power and Mine Supply Company Limited of Winnipeg, who quoted on manual remotely controlled equipment, are not in accordance with our specification and are not suitable.

The purchase prices of equipment in accordance with our specification offered by the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company Limited of Ottawa and Medland Machinery Limited of Winnipeg is in the amount of $5,660 with eight weeks delivery and $5,660 with six to eight months delivery, respectively.

In view of the above, particularly in connection with the delivery dates, which is important because of the urgent need of lighting plant equipment, we suggest that the order be placed with the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company Limited of Ottawa.

The equipment which we consider necessary, listed by this firm in their tender, includes the following:

(a) Generating unit complete with all necessary wiring - $5,454.00

(b) Automatic shut down for low lube oil pressure and high water temperature - 154.00

(c) Flexible exhaust tubing - 3 feet with M & F connections - 35.00

(d) 20 feet of exhaust piping 2" diameter - 17.00

Total cost f.o.b.Lloydminster, Saskatchewan - $5,660.00

We assume that the existing facilities for fuel oil storage can be used for the operation of this new equipment and the other items listed under Optional Equipment Required need not be purchased.

We are enclosing herewith tenders forwarded to this Division.

Enclos.

Chief Engineer.

Colonel Neary:

ONION LAKE (RC) INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

Only a brief visit to this school was possible today.

Some of the points requiring attention are:

1. Water Supply: A tractor has to be used to furnish the electric power to operate the pressure tank. This is awkward and expensive. The Postman has telegraphed requesting Fairbanks-Morse to accelerate action.

2. Lighting: also dependent on the tractor.

3. Enrollment: School not working at full potential. Ninety-seven present. It could handle 150.

4. Health: An epidemic of chicken-pox has overtaxed infirmary space and necessitated make-shift arrangements. Nearest doctor is 35 miles distant, but one of the nuns is a Registered Nurse.

5. Bathrooms: The inspection report should be studied.

6. Kitchen Range: Curry-Oxford. The makers should be queried re the possibility of supplying spare parts.

7. Dishwashing: This is done in the dining room.

8. Laundry: The Principal claims the ventilation is poor. I suggested a fan to force out the air.

9. Fire extinguishers: Require checking and re-filling.

10. Bakery: Health and Welfare to be requested to suggest best material for making dough-bin covers.

Attention: Owner, Manager or Superintendent

Dear Sir:

The following extracts from the Boiler & Pressure Vessel Act 1948, are particularly drawn to your attention.

Section 14 An inspection certificate may set forth repairs or alterations to be made in, upon or in connection with any boiler, pressure vessel or plant, and the owner shall cause such repairs to be executed forthwith.

Section 15 Every inspection certificate shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the plant or near the boiler or pressure vessel to which it relates and shall be produced by the owner or other person responsible for or in immediate charge of such boiler, pressure vessel or plant upon demand of an inspector.

Section 20 (1) No owner shall cause or permit any high pressure boiler or steam plant to be operated unless:
(a) a chief engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as chief engineer, and who is not responsible for the operation of any other boiler or steam plant, is responsible for and personally supervises the operation thereof; and
(b) either such chief engineer or a shift engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as shift engineer is in immediate charge thereof and the chief engineer, shift engineer or some other person acting under the direct supervision of the chief engineer or shift engineer is in personal attendance on the boiler at all times, whether or not any such boiler is equipped with automatic control.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), no owner shall cause or permit any low pressure boiler or steam plant having a capacity of twenty horse power or more to be operated unless a person who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant is responsible for the operation thereof and in personal attendance thereon at all times.

(3) A low pressure boiler having a capacity of not more than seventy-five horse power which is equipped with an automatic low-water cut-out device approved by an inspector and designed to shut off the fuel fire in the event of low water, may be left unattended and in operation for a period not exceeding ten consecutive hours if:
(a) the safety valve is set to relievel at not more than fifteen pounds to the square inch;
(b) the safety valve and automatic low-water cut-out device are tested daily to ensure their efficient operation; and
(c) the automatic low-water cut-out device is installed in such manner that it cannot be rendered inoperative by the manipulation of any manual control or regulating apparatus and the water column, water glass and the float chamber of the cut-out device may be thoroughly blown out each day.

Section 27 Every owner of a boiler, pressure vessel or plant shall provide and keep at all times in a readily accessible location an adequately equipped first aid kit for the treatment of minor injuries and shall produce such first aid kit upon demand of an inspector.

Our inspectors report that in some instances owners are employing persons to operate boilers who do not hold certificates issued under the Act and we sincerely hope that after receipt of this notice such violations will be corrected making further action unnecessary.

Your full co-operation in respect to all the requirements of the Act is solicited in the interests of public safety and will be greatly appreciated.

Further to our conversation in Frenchman's Butte concerning the water-softener ordered for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School and your instructions for me to wire the Purchasing Agent for instructions re: the shipping of the water-softener now held by the C.N.R. at Frenchman's Butte:

I felt that I would like to investigate the case further and I found in interviewing Mr. W. Zier, the plumber who installed the water-softener, that the Principal, Father St. Pierre, ordered this softener from Mr. Zier of Lloydminster on June 9th. At that time a sample of the water used in the school was submitted to the firm making water softeners to be analyzed and the firm found that there had to be a special type of water softener used with this type of water. A check on our correspondence on file here goes to show that this water softener was ordered prior to this office knowing anything about it.

I find it necessary to report that the principal of this school has on numerous occasions in the past ordered equipment and then afterwards submitted same to this office for payment. He knows full well that this is contrary to policy and on one other occasion I have been reprimanded for okaying materials he had previously purchased. I feel that some sort of action should be taken to stop this in the future.

I notice the difference in the price that Zier charged for the Water-softener EH90 and the Departmental Purchase Order price is $78.25. Seeing that the softener was installed prior to July 15th would recommend payment on the basis of the Departmental Purchase Order price, namely $391.00 and that Father St. Pierre be asked to pay the difference that and the Zier price or $469.25, and that the Departmental Purchasing Agent also ask him to pay the return freight on this softener which the Department ordered and which now lies in the C.N.R. station at Frenchman's Butte. In fairness to all concerned I feel that Father St. Pierre should pay the difference seeing he went ahead and made the purchase unauthorized.

J.A. Davis
Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.

Re: Your letter of November 23, file 2761-171/6-1-659.

Wish to state that we inspected this school on the evening that I left you at Onion Lake and before submitting this report would like to draw your attention to the fact that this office did not receive a copy of the fire inspector's report and the only way that I knew that the fire inspector had made an inspection was that I happened to see the fire inspector's report at the school. May I suggest that a request be made that the fire inspector in the future supply the Agency offices with a copy of their report in order that we may take whatever action is recommended.

The Inspector's report brings out the following:

1. Install a cement block on exhaust pipe on diesel engine in basement.
   This work has now been carried out and completed.

2. Protect the wall behind the laundry stoves in basement with heavy asbestos.
   This has been completed.

3. One laundry stove was found with the fire box burned out and this should be replaced.
   My inspection showed that now all three stoves are burned out and I recommended to the Father Principal that these be replaced at once.

4. Install approved fire doors on boiler room. These to be self closing or held open by fusible links.
   The Father Principal has had part of this work done and is now awaiting further supplies from Sterling Mills, North Battleford, to complete same.

5. All three metal fire escapes to be extended to ground level.
   The carpenter now has this work about half done.
6. Fire escape doors on all floors to be changed to open outwards, and the same to be equipped with panic bolts.

The Father Principal has ordered this from Sterling Mills, North Battleford, and has the men ready to install them as soon as the material arrives.

7. Illuminated Exit signs to be installed over all doors leading to fire escapes.

The Father Principal has ordered the wire and expects the same to arrive any day when he will have same installed.

8. Fire alarm system is inadequate and should be extended to each dormitory with an alarm bell and an alarm station.

The principal ordered this equipment which arrived the other day and is having same installed.

9. All 2½ gal. Soda Acid fire extinguishers are to be recharged annually and hung on brackets three feet from the floor. Each extinguisher should also have a dated tag affixed and a record kept of each recharging.

Re: Your file 3010-171-16-S, dated Dec.15/49.

We attach copies of the correspondence in connection with the estimates referred to in the above file for the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, No.659.

You will note by the date on the covering letter with Father St. Pierre's list that it was not made out until November 19/49, and was received by this office on Nov.21, 1949. The Father Principal has not quoted prices on any of the objects requested, nor has he given us full details of companies manufacturing such items as "one machine for mending stockings", "one electric mixer", (he does not say whether this is a bread mixer or a general mixer with attachments such as a "mix-master") "one potato peeler", nor does he list what tools are required for the woodwork.

When the Principal of the Beauval Indian R.C. Residential School, Father Gagnon, submits his estimates they are worked out to the last detail. A drawing is given for any proposed buildings, showing approximate distances, areas, and installations required. He submits full quotations of prices of all equipment, where it can be bought, and how much it will come to laid down at Beauval. He also gives full reasons for his requests so that we can see they are definitely needed and the school will suffer for lack of same.

As you very well know from experience the tracking down of companies and prices delivered for the items listed in such a manner as Father St. Pierre has done will take months. First we will have to try to obtain from Father St. Pierre a more accurate description of these items, the company manufacturing same, and then the correspondence with them to obtain quotations laid down at the nearest freight depot.
It is unfortunate that we did not notice that batteries for the lighting plant would be needed and include these in the Estimates for 1950-51. As it is we have not made allowances for any repairs to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. Father St. Pierre had submitted no requests or estimates and we did not realize that any would be needed.

A quick guess at the cost of the items listed for Onion Lake R.C. Residential School appears to be quite a sum. If the roof is in the condition he states it is we cannot see why this matter was not brought to our attention months ago.

We would like to know just how much help the Indian Affairs Branch gives to these Residential Schools. So far we pay for the nightwatchman at Onion Lake, tuition for each pupil attending, repairs and installations, furniture and equipment needed and new additions and repairs to the buildings. What part, besides providing the regular teaching and supervising staff does the R.C. Church provide? Knowing that it is called the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School we believed they paid the upkeep and we just paid for the tuition of the pupils the same as white children's tuition is paid at boarding schools by their parents. We believed any extra help we gave was in the way of encouragement and special grants to thank them for the work they are doing for our Indians. If our Branch is responsible for the entire upkeep of these schools just as we are for our day schools then a more strict watch must be kept to ascertain needed repairs to both buildings and equipment so that same may be made before the expenditure amounts to such large sums.

Beyond the fact that the Father Principal has submitted no cost Estimate we are not complaining but would like to know where we stand with these schools. May we please have your advice on these matters so that no future errors such as this should occur.

J.A. Davis
Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.

Regina, March 4th, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Please refer to my letter dated December 1st, 1949, File
2864-171/6-1-659, with regard to expenditures resulting from
correcting fire hazards at the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

No authority was received from the Department, and no
authority issued from this office for these expenditures. As we
wish to comply with orders of the Provincial Fire Commissioner
it has been customary to submit requisitions to the Department
for that purpose. However, in this case Reverend Father St.
Pierre, the Principal of the School, had proceeded to order
the materials necessary for the work, and I am enclosing Meadow
Lake Agency Voucher No. 160 for $449.45, in favour of Sterling
Hardware & Millworks Limited, North Battleford, covering the
invoices and in accordance with orders issued by Reverend Father
St. Pierre.

I would recommend payment of this voucher because of the
urgency of having the work done, as the Union Lake R.C. Residential
School building is not, by any means, safe, and the least we can
do is to comply with the Fire Commissioner's orders.

The whole thing was done improperly, as indicated in my
letter above referred to, but the damage had been done before I
was aware of it, as, at that time, the Fire Commissioner was not
careful to supply me with a copy of each order issued. So far as
I know, the only one who received the order in this particular
case was the Principal of the School.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

Memorandum:

MAJOR D.M. MACKAY

With reference to our recent conversation regarding certain Principals making purchases without first obtaining authority, I submit for your information the following transaction which occurred in connection with the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

On September 1st, 1949, Regional Supervisor Ostrander forwarded to us a letter he had received from Superintendent Davis of the Meadow Lake Agency, enclosing a requisition for a water softener for the Onion Lake School. We forwarded the requisition to the Departmental Purchasing Agent and the softener was subsequently purchased.

When the softener reached the freight address of the school, Superintendent Davis made further enquiries and found that the Principal, Father St. Pierre, had ordered the water softener from Mr. William Zier of Lloydminster, a local plumber, on June 9th without the knowledge of the Superintendent. Therefore, the softener we supplied was not required and we transferred it to the Gordon's Indian Residential School, where it could be used.

Recently we received an account covering the cost of the softener, and I may add that Mr. Zier charged considerably more than the price at which we could have purchased the softener.

You will note from the above that considerable work was caused to several of our officials and that the
expenditure was incurred without any authority, and consequently, we are returning the voucher unpaid and requesting Superintendent Davis to notify the Principal that its cost will have to be paid from school funds.

PP/7T

J.P.B. Ostrander, Esq.,

Regina, Sask.

Father St. Pierre has informed us that fire broke out in the barn at the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School and before being brought under control caused damage estimated at $1,000.00. This fire was on March 1st and was caused by the motor on the milking machine back-firing and the carburetor immediately took fire. This fire spread to the straw above. In about 15 to 20 minutes the pupils and the men of the school had connected about four to five hundred feet of hose to the water system and pumped water into the fire which soon brought it under control.

The Father Principal approves very much of their water system which he states saved them from a loss of about $5,000.00. He has asked that our Department aid them in repairing the roof, the north half or side of the building also, are destroyed. We have written to him asking that he submit a list of the supplies required and their approximate cost so that we may submit same to Ottawa and ask for their authorization to repair same. We definitely told him that we cannot authorize the repair until these lists have been sent to Ottawa and they authorize the repair through this office.

The Father Principal states that they themselves will do the labour of repairing.

Trust this is the correct procedure in notifying you of damage by fire to school properties.

There has been some leaking in the roof of the
Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, main building. I
asked Indian Superintendent Davis, of the Meadow Lake Agency,
to investigate the matter in an effort to ascertain whether
or not it would be necessary to undertake a major repair job.
Apparently he has made a rough guess that the whole of the roof
needs re-covering, and has obtained a price from Panther Oil
and Grease Manufacturing Company, of Toronto, for 8,663 sq. ft.
of surface, at a cost of $855.00.

I have discussed the matter with Mr. W.W. Perrie,
and we are of the opinion that it is quite probable that only
minor repairs are needed, possibly two or three leaks in the roof,
and, in any case, ordinary asphalt can be used at a cost consider-
ably less than the quotation Mr. Davis has obtained.

I would recommend that the matter be left in abeyance
until the roads become passable, and the weather more suitable,
after which Mr. Perrie be asked to send an engineer to investigate
the matter and make a recommendation.

In the meantime I am instructing Mr. Davis to take
no further action.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

Saskatchewan.

On June 27th, as per your instructions, I visited the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School, but was unable to obtain much information due to the absence of the Principal and his Assistant.

I examined the roof of the school building, and found the same to be in need of extensive repair. In my opinion the roof of the main building will have to be entirely recovered, although I feel the wings can be satisfactorily repaired. I would suggest asking contractors for tenders for this job as soon as possible.

The fire escapes and doors have been repaired or constructed to comply with recommendations outlined by Mr. Tiffin in his report dated June 1st, 1950, although the self-closing doors have not yet been installed on the doors leading to the dormitories from the stairways. This will be done as soon as possible.

I examined the lighting plant and batteries at the school, and find that they have not been properly cared for. This may be due to lack of knowledge on the part of the mechanic. I have, however, instructed him on the proper procedure, care, and operation of this plant and batteries. I was informed by the mechanic that during the winter months they had some trouble with the Fairbanks-Morse Diesel Unit, and for a temporary measure they used an old generator that the school had in its possession, and used the McCormack-Deering tractor to supply the power to drive this generator. The proper control panel for this generator was not available or used, and resulted in too fast an over-charging of the batteries. This will naturally shorten the life of the batteries. However, if the control for the Fairbanks-Morse Diesel engine which ordinarily supplies this power to re-charge these batteries is set properly to start with, they should charge at the rate of 20 amps. As the batteries become charged, and the resistance increases, the amperage naturally is retarded. To overcome this, the mechanic had been increasing the voltage by advancing the Rehostat. This increases the voltage and causes the batteries to heat. I explained the danger this caused to the batteries, to him, and he stated that he had not had too much experience, and no course in maintaining Diesel engines or lighting units, but instructed me to make sure our recommendations. He also informed me that Father St. Pierre, the Principal of the School, tinkered with the machines quite frequently.

The Diesel engine itself is operating very well, but the electrically controlled shut-off is very sticky. This will require a highly skilled workman to repair it properly, therefore I would recommend that we remove the pumps and solonide and have the same repaired by an expert.

Apart from the engine room, the...
Apart from the engine room, the rest of the school appeared tidy and clean. I instructed the caretaker to clean the shavings and rags, etc. off the oil soaked floor of this combination engine room and shop.

There must be an accompanying letter to explain this. It's all new to me.

Re: Onion Lake Indian Residential School Barn (R.C.)

As per your instructions I visited the above mentioned school on July 26th, and, in checking the boiler described by Mr. Davis in his requisition for supplies, I find that I am unable to obtain any further information from the boiler plates. It is described as a McLarney's Farmer Boiler, No. 30. From the information I have obtained from different sources this type of boiler was originally made for scalding hogs on the farm. I would suggest that a small boiler be purchased and installed in the furnace room, the steam and hot water be piped to the laundry, and the three formerly mentioned boilers be done away with.

Barn - the repairs to the roof from the fire had been completed but there is evidence of much carelessness in the maintenance of the rest of the building. The doors are sinking and sprung, and no attempt has been made to repair them. One stanchion in the cow barn is broken, and was left lying in the stall, along with other broken material which has not been piled, but more or less thrown into this stall.

A lean-to on the east end of the blacksmith's shop is badly in need of minor repairs and the roof is sinking. It would require very little effort on the part of the Principal to have this roof repaired (jacked and re-braced). All buildings at the school, with the exception of a blacksmith's shop, are in immediate need of minor repairs.

The school barn yard is generally in an untidy condition

with bricks and bit of broken....
with bricks and bits of broken plank lying here and there. I also found that a roller jack which had apparently been used to jack up the tractor was left lying in the yard where they had finished with it, and the tractor, or whatever machine was being repaired, had been moved away.

On a visit to this school on July 18th I drew Father St. Pierre's attention to the shavings and rubble lying about the combination work shop and engine room, and pointed out to him the fire hazard this created, but on my visit on the 24th I found there were more shavings and rubble, and no attempt had been made to clean it. It is evident that Father St. Pierre is not too fire conscious, as I also found a two-gallon can partly filled with gasoline, and one of the caps on the can was missing. This can is kept in the engine room in the barn close to the engine used to operate the milking machine. This is the same engine that is supposed to have started the fire in the barn earlier this year. I pointed out these things to Mr. J.A. Davis, Superintendent, Meadow Lake Agency, and he informed me that he had, on several previous occasions, mentioned some of these things to Father St. Pierre, but had received no reply regarding any of them.

I would recommend that another fire proof building of sheet steel or some other fire proof material be built 10 or 12 ft. away from the barn, and the engine that is now in the barn be put in this building.

D.N. Morrison,

We wish to express our most sincere thanks to the Officials of the Department of Indian Affairs for the Globelite Batteries which were just received for our electric plant. These will be installed as soon as we find time to do so. I wish to assure that special attention will be given to take proper care of them and that we will carry out the recommendations made by the Supervisor of Construction.

Although there are a few points for us to be more careful I wish to mention that you have, in some way, been misinformed concerning the use of a McCormack-Deering tractor to supply power to drive the generator for charging batteries, as this has not been done since we have the Fairbanks-Morse Diesel Unit. It is true that we did have some trouble with the generator, but we have been without electricity for two months, using gas and oil lamps for lighting purposes. The only use that was made of the tractor was to operate the laundry machine and dryer by placing a belt directly on the pulley at the end of this machine, so, the tractor had nothing to do with the electric plant.

I have been informed also that the mechanic did increase the voltage by advancing the Rehestat but this was done after the motor starter had been replaced on the Fairbanks-Morse Diesel engine, as we still had trouble with it then, but this will not be done again and besides, this mechanic is not here anymore. Thanking you for all consideration given, I remain

Dear Sir:

With further reference to my letter of July 8th last, and your reply to the same on July 16th. (No.115-8-10), and your further letter of September 20th. (No.118-8-10) setting forth your understanding of the circumstances under which the two Anglican Indian children, Thomas and Emma Moyah, were admitted to the Roman Catholic Onion Lake School, I beg to state that I have been instructed by our Commission to correct some of the information you have received, and on which the decision set forth in your letter of September 20th appears to have been based.

1. In your letter of September 20th. you state that "It is found, however, that no children in this family have been baptized since the year 1923..." This is incorrect, as the Rev. Principal Ellis of our Union Lake School baptized the youngest child in this family, a baby girl seven months old, on October 6th. of this year, when it received the name of Caroline Edna. The other children previously baptized into the Church of England were as follows:

Mary baptized January 4th. 1914
Alice Harriet " December 5th. 1915
Thomas " December 7th. 1917
Emma " March 16th. 1922
Gladys Reima " June 9th. 1925
Isadore " June 3rd. 1928

2. You also state in your letter of September 20th. that "the Department has received definite information to the effect that the father is a regular attendant at the Roman Catholic Church, and that the family are now recognized as Roman Catholics." As Pierre Moyah the father of the above
children was baptized into the Church of England on December 25th, 1932, and his youngest child "Caroline Edna" was likewise baptized on October 6th, 1933, and his daughter Mary married in the Church of England on October 7th, 1933. Our Commission are not convinced that this family is "now recognized as Roman Catholics." As Pierre Moyan appears, from information received by our Commission, to have recently admitted to the local Indian Agent, Dr. J. T. Hill, that the Church of England record with regard to his baptism into our Church on December 25th, 1932, was correct, and that the records with regard to the baptism of his children into our Church on the dates given were also correct, the members can see no justification whatever for the admission of Thomas and Emma Moyan into the Roman Catholic School, and they trust that your Department, with this fuller knowledge of the circumstances before it, may view the matter in the same light and have them transferred to our Society's School where they rightly belong. In expressing this opinion our Commission take the view that your Department's ruling that children of Protestant parents must be admitted to Protestant Schools, and children of Roman Catholic parents must be admitted to Roman Catholic Schools, should be carefully observed, if serious confusion is to be avoided, and anything like stability in the system of administration is to be secured and maintained.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, December 2, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with further reference to the admission of Thomas and Emma Moyah to the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School.

As you were informed in official letter of September 20th last, the Department has been definitely informed that Moyah is a regular attendant at the Roman Catholic Church and that the family are now recognized as Roman Catholics. On this understanding, the admission of the children to the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School was approved. In taking such action, the Department was adhering strictly to the intention of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act.

I note you are not convinced that the Moyah family are recognized as Roman Catholics. In view of the information given in your letter, I am obtaining a further report.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

In the last paragraph of your No. 99-19 of July 26th last, you stated that Moyah was a regular attendant at the Roman Catholic Church and, as you had approved the application for the admission of his children to the Roman Catholic School, the Department assumed you were satisfied that the Moyah family are now recognized as Roman Catholics.

The Department is now in receipt of a letter from Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, Field Secretary, M.S.O.C., in which he states that he is not convinced this family should be recognized as Roman Catholics. He states that the youngest child of this family was baptized in the Anglican Church on October 6, 1933, and that Moyah's daughter, Mary, was married in the Church of England on October 7, 1933.

I would appreciate if you would again make careful enquiry regarding the previous religious affiliations of the Moyah family and advise the Department whether or not, in your opinion, there has been any recent change.

With reference to the above, in the late p.m. of even date
a telephone message was received from W. Hayes, sure keeper
at Onion Lake, Sask. to the effect that he had received word
by telephone from the authorities of the R.C. Indian Mission
School, that three SISTERS and a Indian boy had started
out for Onion Lake, with a team and sleigh about 5.00 p.m.
and as it was now 9.30 p.m., they had not yet returned home.
I was advised by W. Hayes that the sisters had not been to
the store and as they had not reached home at this late
hour they feared they must be lost in the storm, as it had
been snowing and blowing all day.

I then notified Dr J.T. Hall Indian Agent at Onion
Lake, who informed me that he would send
a number of men would go from the agency and
start in search of the lost parties. I notified Dr Hill
to join the searching party as soon as possible. I
then left Onion Lake per Police S.W.#2030 and patrolled
east of the Indian Agency and district, thence to the home of Dr J.
Hill.

Whilst waiting at the home of Dr Hill's for the searching
party, a telephone message was received by Dr Hill from the
authorities at the R.C. Mission School to the effect that
the lost parties had returned home to the Mission escorted
by John Muskogee an Indian with a fresh team of horses, as
the team the lost parties were driving had tired out.

Upon receiving this information that the lost parties
were safely at home at the Mission, I returned to my
Detachment in the early a.m. of the 21-12-33.

CONCLUDED.

NO EXPENSE INCURRED.

21-2-34.

I then returned to Onion Lake and wired the N.G.O. in charge Turtleford Detachment to be on the lookout for these boys as they were no doubt headed for Thunderchild Indian Reserve (Archie PADDY's home is there).

22-2-34.

3. I immediately got in touch with the Indian Agent in regard to this matter, and he informed me that he would send a team to Turtleford the next morning and convey these children back to the R.C.Mission. I then wired Turtleford Detachment to this effect.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the June quarter return of the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School.

The Department has not yet received your reply to the Deputy Superintendent General's circular letter of the 15th ultimo. You will note from that circular that the Indian Act requires that, when pupils are being kept in a residential school after they reach the age of sixteen years, permission must be secured. You should, therefore, forward a list of all pupils in the school at the present time who are sixteen years of age and over, and in the case of those whom you consider should be kept for a longer period, permission should be requested, and your reasons given for asking such permission.

Sir:

I am forwarding herewith the names of our Indian children over sixteen years of age:

132 Therese Matchisikak, 20. Orphan no home, no near relatives to take care of her. She goes for a little vacation and comes back immediately. She has been here at the school since she was 5 years old, having been brought here by the police after both her father and mother had died during the Flu Epidemic. Permission already granted last year to keep her until she marries Peter Matchisikak, her same case than Therese his sister.

143 William Maskego, orphan 17. Will probably get married soon desires to stay until he gets married. Has only an aged uncle to look after him.

147 Johnny Paul, orphan no father or mother.

204 Charlie Daniel: Discharged at the end of June

223 Edward Kamiskikitw: 16. Came very late at the school. Only 1/2 year schooling. Knows very little and needs more training.

164 Eliza Maskego, 16. Orphan. Her father remarried and is very sick. Cannot look after her. She is not very strong and needs good care. The Indian agent here advised her to remain at school.

165 Mary Wolfe, 16. Orphan no body to take care of her and stays here during vacation.

184 Anne Angus, 17. Will probably get married late at the Fall. She stays here at the school during vacation having no body to look after her except her aged grandmother who is very poor. I like to keep her until she gets married and by this to keep her out of trouble.

241 Philomene Stanley, 16. Came late to the school and is very late in her studies. Had no yet any chance to get training for house work.

245 M. Rose Whitstone, 16. Same as above name Philomene Stantle.

For reasons which I name below we have always been desirous of keeping the children until they are eighteen years of age and the Indian Agent...
L.J.C. & M.I.

is in entire agreement with us.

In many cases the children do not come until they are nine to twelve years of age, which is late to begin. If possible we keep children steadily at school until they are sixteen years and by this time they have reached Grades VI and VII. Occasionally we have them doing Grade VIII work where they are sufficiently intelligent.

At sixteen they begin to train for house work and Farming.

Now if the children leave us at sixteen, they cannot possibly be self-supporting; as there has not been time to give them an appreciable amount of training, but if the Department and the Agent are willing to advance further help we will be only too happy to give the children every possible advantage to fit them for an independent future.

Some of them who stay with us marry before they leave the school.

If my suggestion be supported by the Department it is my intention when the children have reached the age of seventeen to have them go home in the Spring to break land, then have them return to school the following year they can then put in their crop and if they wish to marry they will later have a little money and a home to start with. In this way I consider they will become more ambitious and self-supporting and in a position to live apart from the old people.

From experience we find that when the children leave us as early as sixteen nearly all the good work that has been expended on their behalf is of no avail. They are just out for the fun they can get, they become more lazy and irresponsible and by the time they are mature men and women they are no further ahead than were their parents before them. We feel very strongly on this point and trust that the Department will see eye to eye with us in this matter.

Yours very truly

ST. ANTHONY'S SCHOOL

Headquarters:
1. With reference to the above, on this date while in Cold Lake, Alberta, I was informed by the Mother of the above named that he and his wife had separated and that Stanley should be in School. Stanley was with his Mother. This same date I met Mr. Hill, Indian Agent of Onion Lake, in Cold Lake and informed of this matter and he instructed me to investigate the case. I then made enquiries about Cold Lake, but was unable to locate the above named. I remained in Cold Lake overnight.

Sub-Division:
2. In the A.M. of this date I patrolled per Pte. Auto to Cold Lake Indian Reserve and after making numerous enquiries I finally located the above named and his Mother. I found that the above named was sick in bed, and that arrangements had been made with Father Pratt of the R.C.Mission, whereby Father Pratt would come to Cold Lake about the middle of September and take Stanley back with him to Onion Lake.

Detachment:
3. I then patrolled to Onion Lake.

Expense statement submitted.

CONCLUDED.

Constable,

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following with reference to Meise Pascal. Pascal, a Chipewyan treaty Indian, was recently committed to a mental hospital for treatment and will be there for an indefinite period. His wife, whom he married last year, was a widow (non-treaty) with three children aged respectively, 7, 9, and 11 years. Mrs. Pascal has asked me to have these children admitted to the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Onion Lake. Should the Department consider this I would be pleased to forward the admission forms duly completed. The children have no opportunity to get an education where they are, and, in addition, will be a charge on the Department until their step-father returns.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent,

The Secretary,

Ottawa.
J.C. & M.I.

Re: Sam Cook

come to see you on account of my children. You already know that I have placed two of my children at the C.E. School. With reference to this last boy, he has been away several times, he is still home, he does not like the school. Mr. Ellis came four times before the admission of the boy; he wanted me to sign the boy's admission. The last time he came he promised me $100.00 that is to say, he wanted give me the job to haul wood for the sum of $100.00 this winter. It was tempting; so I signed the admission but telling him that I was not decided to send the boy now, but a little later. I brought wood to school for the sum of $50.00 after which I sent the boy. But the moment the boy had entered the school, Ellis forgot all about his promise. I told him then that I was not selling my boy for the sum, simply I claimed that he would keep his word and would keep mine. So he told me to make ten more cords of wood when this was done he refused to buy them, so the cords are still here. He did not keep his word so I cannot trust him any longer, neither will I believe his teaching. So I told him I was breaking off completely both with him and his teaching so saying I handed him his Bible and books.

Re: to my truant boy, the Agent has urged me to send him to school, I objected that I had no means to go that far, he then offered to take me and the boy in his car. I thanked him and said I really did not to send the boy now. So the agent did not argue any more but a few days later, the Police came and took my boy to school, but in a short time he was back again and he is now home.

I then went to find the Agent and told him, I was breaking off with the Church of England and return to my own religion and that I wanted all my children to do likewise. He objected that I might perhaps have a hard time to do so, as my children were now all enrolled at the C.E. School. I said "I do not see why I would have trouble since my children have all been baptized in the R.C. Church, and that I was married in the R.C. Church, that I did not belong to that church years ago and my wife likewise is a Catholic and so was my first wife."

Still I am willing to have the children finish term of three months but after this I desire that my children will be transferred. The Agent told me he would write to the Indian Dept. to explain the matter and do his best to help me.

Signed

Sam Cook
Indian

Witness Joe Quincy.

Onion Lake, Sask., April 23, 1934.

Re to Mr. Edward Fox & Child.

Beth Mr. and Mrs. Edward Fox are here again this evening, to say that they desire to have their girl admitted in the R.C. School, being Catholics they want their children to be of the same creed.

Mr. Edward Fox now admits that he did sign the admission of his girl for both schools, but he added, "If I did sign for the C.E. School, it was through vexation. I was continually harassed by my father-in-law, Joe Waskahat to send my daughter to the C.E. School."

Beth Mr. and Mrs. Fox state that on one occasion, at table a discussion on the child's schooling arose. Mr. J. Waskahat was most imperative in his wish to send the girl to the C.E. school but Mr. Fox refused to comply with his request, when the dispute was at its hottest, Edward left the room saying, "Take the child wherever you wish," this he said, to get rid of the row and have peace. Mrs. Fox, for her part did not want to grieve her parents in going against their wishes so she suggested that the girl should be given to the grandparents. Later she sought the Agent's advice on the matter, Mr. Cameron who was present objected, saying that both father and mother being alive, it was impossible to do so.

Some time after the fact mentioned, Mr. J. Waskahat drove up, he was accompanied by J. Heathen, accountant, both Waskahat and Heathen pressed on Mr. E. Fox to sign the admission of his daughter into the Anglican school, they drove him up to the school and there disregarding his determination not to send the girl to school, Edward signed the admission in order to free himself from his harassing relatives, for he was in no hurry to send his daughter, he declared.

Lasee said he, "I met the Indian Agent who inquired where I intended to send my boy. I replied, I did not want to be bothered with the question, but if ever I decide to send him to school I'll send him wherever I please." My wife added, "It is alright for him to be a Roman Catholic. To this the Indian Agent replied, "See here, I do not favour one school more than the other, I simply want these children where they belong, any way, by the time you will be ready to send your boy to school, I'll perhaps not be an Indian Agent then."

Beth the Indian Agent and Mrs. Ellis are notified that the boy will be placed in the R.C. School.
Regarding the baptism of Marie Ann (my first born). It is a fact that the child was baptized in the R.C. Church two days after her birth; the mother herself took the baby to church accompanied by the godmother, Mrs. Joe Little Wolf, who is here present. This took place the 6th of May 1936. Later when the child was over a year old, Rev. O. Ahnakee re-baptized her. It happened that Rev. Ahnakee was at Onion Lake and was leaving for Lloydminster with Mrs. Jankinhat; the latter sent his daughter Mrs. E. Fox to see Mr. Ahnakee, she did so, and he asked her to baptize the baby; he offered a blanket in return, she accepted.

As a proof that both adhere to the Roman Catholic Church, seven children born from their union have been baptized in the R.C. Church and five of these have been attended by the R.C. priest at their burial.

Ed Fox

Joe Little Wolf

Mrs. Fox

Mrs. J. Little Wolf

Ottawa, October 31st, 1934.

Dear Father Pratt,

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to applications for the admission of certain children to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

We do not appear to have had any correspondence with reference to Maurice Fox. Is this boy a brother of Maria Ann Fox? If so, I would refer you to official letter of February 13th, last, addressed to the former Principal, Rev. Jos. Fortier, O.M.I.

With reference to Sam Cook, we have had considerable correspondence regarding his children. Four members of Sam Cook's family are stated to have been in the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School since 1910 and two of them are attending the C.E. School at the present time. We have no record of any previous protest against the admission of Cook's children to the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School. The statement made by Cook does not indicate any reason why, if he is a Roman Catholic, he has, for the last twenty-four years, been placing his children in the Onion Lake C.E. School.

Let me assure you that cases such as this receive our very careful consideration and we endeavour to be fair to all parties concerned but I think you will realise that it is rather difficult, without more definite information, to accept Cook's statement at its face value now in view of his actions during the past twenty-four years.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. J. E. Pratt, O.M.I.,
Principal,

Fr. J.E. Pratt o.m.i. Principal
March 8th 1935

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have delayed answering your letter dated Oct. 21 last hoping that a settlement would be reached in the meantime concerning the Cooke's children to be admitted here at this school.

These people are Catholics but unfortunately have been for a number of years not faithful Catholics. For over two years they are regular to assist at Mass and come regularly to perform their religious duties as Catholics.

They have one boy admitted at the Anglican School and for this boy I am not concerned because he is legally admitted there. They have two other children who have been baptised in infancy and not yet been in school. I have made in due form and in good faith their applications for admission and I hear from the Indian Agency that they are refused from Ottawa.

The young boy Simon has been here three months last year and I had let him go because he was not admitted yet. The mother comes every Sunday with her children to leave them here at the school and always tell her to wait till the question with the Indian Dept be settled. Already four applications have been made and always the same answer not admitted by Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan I am not asking any favor but only justice. These two children are Catholics and their parents are both Catholics and all parties concerned are Catholics. It is only fair and just that the children be given the right to be raised Catholic and receive an instruction in a Catholic school.

I ask you, Dear Mr. Phelan, to consider the question with justice and obtain from the Dept. the permission to take in this school these two children.

To prove that the parents are sincere I am inclosing a copy of an "Affidavit given sometimes ago" which Affidavit was asked for to prove that they are really Catholics and wish to remain and consider always as Catholics.

As you say in your letter you are ready to give to this case a very careful consideration and be fair to all. It is why I ask you for the sole benefit of the children the permission to admit them here in this school.

I repeat what I have said before in some of my letters to the Dept. I will not try to make any trouble or difficulty to the Dept. but only when a case needs explanation, to take the liberty to lay down openly the facts as truly known to me.

Hoping to receive from the Dept. a favorable reply.

I remain Yours very truly

ST. ANTHONY'S SCHOOL

[Signature]

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-8-10, of the 18th ultimo, with reference to Sam Cook's religion.

The C. of E. records show that he was baptized an Anglican by the Rev. John Pritchard in 1887. Four of his children have been educated in the C. of E. Indian Residential School, and two are in residence at the present time. Five of his children are deceased and are buried in the C. of E. Cemetery. His son James Cook was married to an ex-pupil of the R. C. School on July 15th, 1933, the Rev. H. Ellis performing the ceremony. Sam Cook's wife and James Cook's wife are active members of the Women's Auxiliary in connection with the C. of E., and were in attendance at a meeting on the 17th instant. The records show that all the children of Sam Cook's family were baptized by Anglican curates.

The R. C. records show that Sam Cook and his wife are attending at present and have been for more than a year. Simon Cook, born on August 20th, 1927, was baptized by a Rev. Father on the same date. Sarah Cook, born on December 27th, 1929, was baptized a mother on January 27th, 1930. James Cook and wife were married again by the Rev. Father Pratt on July 3rd, 1934. James Cook's daughter, born March 24th, 1935, was baptized by the Rev. Father Pratt on the same date.

Sam Cook and his family have always been recognized as Anglicans. Just over a year ago Sam had a dispute with Rev. Mr. Ellis about some wood that he was delivered at the C. of E. School, although Mr. Ellis had allowed him more wood than he was entitled to; he still requested more and was refused. Immediately after, Sam severed his connection with the Anglican Church. Interviewed personally by me this week, through the interpreter he definitely told me that he was now a Roman Catholic and desired to have his two remaining children educated in the R. C. School. The two children in question are Simon and Sarah. Simon is seven years old and should enter school this year. Sarah is not yet of school age.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 11th, 1935.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your 99-19 of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the religion of Sam Cook, who has applied for the admission of his two youngest children to the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School.

The Department has carefully considered the information contained in your letter but we are not prepared to decide, at the present time, what school these children should attend.

The two children should not be placed in any Indian residential school until definite instructions are received from the Department. You might again bring up this matter about October 1st and, at that time, you should state whether or not Sam Cook is still desirous of having his two children placed in the Onion Lake R. C. School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa:

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I would like to keep in this school for the next scholar year the following Indian Pupils over 16 years of age, and for the special reasons mentioned:

# 160 Gabriel Lewis 16 only, only starting to make good here, and needs more complete manual training.

# 164 Johnny Badger 16 only, for same reason as #160.

# 188 David John 16, doing very well at the school, needs a more complete manual training, and I intend to start him up good reserve when leaving the school or discharge.

# 216 Edward Cardinal 15 has been at the school only 3 years.

# Louis Harper 15. His father wants his badly to stay at the school. He is doing very good at the school, has strong capacities for mechanic and I give him with the farm training a mechanic training. Like very much to keep him up to 16 as he is well disposed.

# 0164 Eliza *askego* 17. Has been delayed in her manual training through her Grand Father's illness, but is doing very good. She strongly desires to stay one more year with us and also intends to marry before leaving the school.

# 0165 Mary Wolfe 17. Needs a more manual training and also has no proper place to go if leaving the school this coming Summer. She always stays at the school every vacation.

# 0175 Nora Chocan 17. Has no proper home to go she is an adopted child will get married at the school before leaving. She is a very good child and deserves consideration.

# 0177 Josephine Dion 15. Needs a more complete training, has no father or mother but only an aged Grand Mother very old. I desire to keep her here in school up to 16. Needs much supervising and a longer formation.

# 0184 Mary Ann Angue 18, desires to come back, and desires also to get married during the year. She has a good party in sight, an ex pupil from this school, a very good boy but he is not ready to get married. Would like to keep this girl until she gets married. She is very good girl good worker intelligent but has no close relatives and if discharge now will have to go to some far relatives and most probably will lose in a short time all her formation and good qualities acquired during her time at the school. Please grant me the permission to keep her on the roll until she gets married during the year and for the very good of this girl.

# 0191 Mary Ann *askego* 17. For more complete manual formation

# 0223 Isabelle Lepoide 17, has come late at the school, and not very strong she requires a good manual training with a very close mental attention. She has stayed at the school during vacation during the last three years, no mother to look after her.

# 0229 Annie Stick 15, has to go home quite often to look after her sick mother, and by the fact she is late in her studies.

# 0241 Philomene Stanley 17. Having come to school only at 13 she is just starting seriously her manual training which is needed badly.
