Dear Mr. Phelan, I hope that you will grant the permission to keep for a further period these children and for the reasons mentioned.

My intention is to establish the school children when leaving the school both boys and girls and by this to see a practical result of the work of our school.

With the cooperation of the Indian Dept., the local Indian Agent, or Farmer Instructor we can easily obtain a fair good result. On my part, those to be discharged next year, e.g. the boys, this Summer will break some land on the reserve V.G. 10 acres and next spring the school will be supplied with enough cattle and milk to keep these boys at the Fall will something immediately to pass the Winter and if possible to get married and have immediately a good home. By keeping them away from the old folks they will better keep the good formation received at the school. It is my greatest desire to help the ex pupils and to establish them on the reserve. Also for the girls getting married at the school I give them a stove a table a bed chairs and necessary dishes for a little home. If the children are allowed to go home too soon they look only for fun cause trouble on the reserve because they have nothing to interest them. They go here and there with no definite object. Also the big girls are easy victims if not properly looked after.

Hoping Dear Mr. Phelan, that the Dept. is prepared to help in every way to continue the very good work of these Boarding schools and the children will be allowed to stay here at the school as requested and for the reasons mentioned in this letter.

With sincere thanks

Yours very sincerely

I am sending you the application of Henry Half illegitimate son of Lawrence Half treaty Indian of your agency, and of Genevieve Patenaude Half breed.

The boy's mother died this last Spring, leaving this boy without any person reliable to take care of the boy except the aged grandmother. As she is very poor and also unable to support herself she brought the boy to my school and in such a case I could not refuse to turn down her request to take the boy especially knowing that the boy was an illegitimate Indian boy. I still have the boy at the school and I apply to you to have his application accepted by the Dept. and if it is possible to have him registered as a Treaty Indian.

This boy practically passed all his life on the Frog Lake Indian Reserve and his mother died there last Spring.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-8-10, of the 16th instant, with an enclosure from Mrs. Pierre Gadwa, and in reply.

Mrs. Gadwa interviewed me on the 5th instant regarding her daughter Margaret whom she said was at the R. C. Indian Residential School "on probation". She explained that she had arranged with the Sisters to have the girl remain with them for a week in the school, and if she adapted herself and liked it, she would apply for her admission; if not, the child would be taken back to Frog Lake to attend the day school there. She said she had received a letter from Margaret stating that she did not like the school and wanted to return to Frog Lake, and that she had come for her. I told her I was agreeable providing she had not committed herself further to the Principal of the School, and cautioned her not to remove the girl without his knowledge and permission. She said she would not, but in spite of this she proceeded to the school, and, in the Principal's absence, took her by force from the Sisters and returned to our office on the following day, September 6th. While in the office I looked up the R. C. School file and found that Margaret Gadwa, 9½ years, the girl in question, was officially admitted into the school on authority of the Department's 115-8-10, of July 3rd, as the result of an application signed by the girl's father on June 16th. I then told Mrs. Gadwa she had misrepresented the case to me and that the child would have to be returned at once to the R. C. School. She refused. I tried moral suasion but it was no use. I then warned her that she was committing an indictible offense and that if she returned to Frog Lake with the child that I would send for them both, and would prosecute her. She went back to Frog Lake and I sent the R. C. M. P. for her and Margaret on the 7th. I had Margaret returned to the school and I fined Mrs. Gadwa $2.00 and costs or ten days in jail. It was my intention...
intention to extend the period for payment of fine and costs if necessary. Mrs. Gadwa is a bad actor generally and was especially defiant on this occasion. There are times when an Agent must exercise his authority if he is to remain in control.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

As requested I am sending in the name of Henry Half's half brother Jos Heathen #245, son of Scotty Heathen. This boy Jos Heathen has been legally and properly admitted.

His mother for whom I had written Mr. Gullion Indian Agent at Saddle Lake had been united but not married to Lawrence Half from Saddle-Lake Band who died not long ago at St. Paul's Hospital. The mother died some few months ago and the boy being from a Treaty Indian was brought to my school and having nobody to look after him except his aged grandmother. It was impossible for me to refuse the boy and before taking any definite step I consulted our local Indian Agent who advised to take the boy and send a letter to Mr. Gullion "Indian Agent at Saddle-Lake" with the proper admission paper.

Hoping that this explanation will prove clearly enough the present case and believing that the Dept. will see no difficulty in admitting this young boy "Really an Indian Boy" and who has nobody to look after him.

I remain

Secondly, I would like to get your permission to receive into the school seven children from the LeGoff and Cold Lake Reserves. Two of these children belong to the Desjardins family, of which we have already been given permission to receive two children. The other five belong to the Desjarlais family. While these children are all half-breeds, their mothers are pure Indian and they are all living on the reserve, the Desjarlais children and their mother living with their grandparents who are Treaty Indians, and as there are no public schools anywhere near these reserves, this is the only opportunity the children have of receiving an education. I would, therefore, appreciate it very much if you would forward the necessary authority for us to receive these children.

"I would like to get your permission to receive into the school seven children from the LeGoff and Cold Lake Reserves. Two of these children belong to the Desjardins family, of which we have already been given permission to receive two children. The other five belong to the Desjarlais family. Is it not possible for the Principal to secure sufficient Treaty Indian children to fill the Onion Lake R. C. School? The Department wishes, as far as possible, to avoid filling our residential schools with half-breeds.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

I attach, for your signature, a letter to His Lordship Bishop Prud'homme, regarding his request that two children of Sam Cook, an Indian of the Onion Lake Band, be transferred from the Church of England Indian Residential School to the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Onion Lake.

For your information, the facts in connection with this case are: Sam Cook, previous to about 18 months ago, was a member of the Anglican Church. He, himself, is an ex-pupil of the Anglican School. He had a dispute with the Principal of the Anglican School over the delivery of a quantity of wood. In consequence, he left the Anglican Church and has now become a member of the Roman Catholic Church. His two eldest children are at present in the Anglican School, having been placed there at his own request, during the time he was a member of the Anglican Church.

It is now requested, as Sam Cook has joined the Catholic Church, that his two children be removed from the Anglican School and placed in the Onion Lake Catholic School.

The Department, in the past, has had similar requests, following a change of religion on the part of a parent. In such cases, it is the practice not to consent to the removal of the child to another school, on any grounds. At present, while Sam Cook is a Roman Catholic,

- there is no
there is no guarantee that he may not again return to
the Anglican Church; when he would request that his
children be taken out of the Catholic School and placed
in an Anglican School. Frequent changes of religion
on the part of an Indian have occurred in the past.

You will see the difficulty occasioned
if transfers of pupils from one school to another were
made. When persistent demand is made on the part of the
parent or the church authorities, to have a child re-
moved from a school, the Department, in such case, grants
the discharge and returns the child to the parent but
refuses to allow the child's entrance to a school of
another religious denomination.

These religious cases are most difficult
to decide and have given the Department much concern
and trouble. When application is made for the admission
of a child to a school and claim is made by two different
denominations, the Department refuses to grant admission
and the child remains at home. It has been found, in
many cases, that when this action is taken, the religious
difficulties adjust themselves.

As requested, I return herewith Bishop
Prud'homme's letter.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, December 13, 1895.

Dear Bishop Prud'homme:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 26th ultimo, regarding the request for the transfer of the two children of Sam Cook, who are at present in residence at the Church of England Indian Residential School, to the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Onion Lake.

In this connection I am informed that Catherine Cook was admitted to the Church of England School in May, 1930, and Edmund Cook, in February, 1934. At that time the father was a member of the Anglican Church and signed the applications requesting their admission to the Anglican Indian Residential School.

Some 18 months ago, the father became a member of the Roman Catholic Church and requested that two younger children be admitted to the Roman Catholic School. The Department ascertained that Sam Cook is now recognized as a Catholic, and, consequently, approval was given for the admission of these two younger children to the Roman Catholic School.

Might I point out that the eldest child has been in the Anglican school for a period of over five years and the second eldest, for approximately two years. It is the practice of the Department, when a child has been admitted to a residential school at the request of a parent, not to transfer such child for religious reasons to a school of another religious denomination.

Yours sincerely,

Jan. 11-1936

After being notified by the Agent Mr. Hill that my children had been admitted to St. Anthony's School, Mr. Ellis, Principal of the R.F. School called to my home saying that he had come for the baby, but I refused to lend him that day. Then he came twice afterwards and my wife said he had a very odd look. Under pressure to cure the evil he told my wife to take the baby to R.F. School which she did. I accompanied her.

Mr. Ellis came along with a piece of paper and asked me to sign it but stating what was written on it. On my inquiry for explanation he urged me to sign saying it was nothing now that my children are at the R.F. School. I am determined to leave them there, and in case where I will be obliged to withdraw them they shall never enter another school.
The paper I signed was given to Archie Puddy to be taken to the Agency. I ask you as a favor to read the contents of the letter I signed. I now see what a mistake I have made in signing this paper, not knowing how to read nor write. As to my religion I am a Roman Catholic, and will remain so to the end of my days.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I was very pleased to receive your very kind answer to our Xmas greetings. This letter is a great encouragement to myself, staff and children. Now, Dear Mr. Sutherland, last Saturday, Jan 10th, Dr. Hill, our Agent, came along and told me he had received from you a letter stating that the Cook's Children's admission has been suspended until April, because a contradictory letter from Mr. Cook himself had reached you in the meantime.

As I have been notified officially of the admission of these children to this R.C. Onion-Lake Residential School and the children having been brought here by their parents themselves and only January the 6th, it is impossible for me to turn them back to their parents after having acted only after an official notification and with no rush. Therefore, Mr. Sutherland, I will wait upon the return of your reply to act.

As soon as Dr. Hill, notified me of your last letter concerning these children, I called in their parents, and told them what news has been received from Ottawa, and also about their supposed letter written by them. The answer is their own letter which I inclose and I say that no pressure has been made to induce them to tell what it is in their letter. More than that, I had an Indian to take their statement in written and after being written was read to them and they explicitly said it was according to the true facts.

The principal of the other Residential School knew perfectly well that these children had been officially admitted here, why did he go and induce the parents to act the way they did?

Dear Mr. Sutherland, I have accepted the Cook's children only after they had been officially admitted by your Dept., and over a month after the official notification.

I cannot be blamed to induce the parents to have their children here or even to have acted rushly.

I have tried to submit myself to the limit of the Dept. wishes and now as everything seemed settled for good comes this bad news.

What shall I do? As the children are and brought here in good faith and after being admitted officially, it is pretty hard for me to let the children go. This case had given enough trouble for the past year I thought it was all over.

The letter enclosed speaks by itself?

I am, for nothing, himself had an Indian to write it and had the same letter read and explained to him.

Dr. Hill, our Indian Agent has certainly observed a very strict neutrality in this present case, and his views met the approbation of the Indians of this Reserve.

Hoping Dear Mr. Sutherland that this letter will receive your most kind and favorable consideration

Dear Sir:

On Dec. 13th last, I furnished you with information that I had received from the Rev. Principal Ellis of our Onion Lake School, that your Department had authorized the admission of Simon and Sarah Cook, children of Anglican Indian parents, to the Roman Catholic School on the Onion Lake Reserve.

In your reply on the 3rd instant, number 115-8-10, you stated that, conflicting reports having been received with reference to the religion of the Father (Sam Cook), it had been decided not to admit his two children to any Indian Residential School during the next few months.

In a further letter received from the Rev. Henry Ellis, Principal of our Society's School, and dated Jan. 24th, he informs me that your ruling in this particular case is not being respected; that he had been informed, and that he had investigated the matter, and found it to be true that both Simon and Sarah Cook have already been admitted to, and were, at the time he wrote his letter, in residence at the Onion Lake Roman Catholic School.

As two other children of the man, Sam Cook, are in residence in our Society's School, namely, Katherine, admitted in May, 1930, and Edwin, admitted Jan. 1934, it will be appreciated if you will inform me of the source of the conflicting reports you have received with reference to the religion of this man at the present time. It will also be appreciated if your Department will take such steps as you may deem
advisable to see that your ruling, as set forth in your letter of the 3rd instant, is carried out. As you state that your representative, the local Indian Agent, Mr. Hill, was informed of the ruling, I am quite at a loss to understand how it could be disregarded. As it seems to me that such action, if allowed to pass without question, may have serious consequences, I beg to recommend that you request your representative to furnish a full explanation in connexion with the same. So far as I learn from the information I have received to date the Roman Catholic Church has no claim whatever on the Indian Sam Cook and his children, so I feel that it would be only fair to our Church to have the two children in question, namely Simon and Sarah Cook, transferred immediately to our Society's School.

I have the honour to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

With further reference to my letters of December 13th last and January 29th last, and your replies to the same on January 3rd last, no. 115-8-10, and February 5th last, no. 115-8-10 re. Simon and Sarah Cook, children of Sam Cook, on the Onion Lake Reserve, Sask. I have been informed by the Principal of our Onion Lake School, that these children, despite the decision set forth in your letter of January 3rd, mentioned above, are still in residence in the Roman Catholic School on the Onion Lake Reserve. If the information I have received is founded on fact, and I haven't the slightest reason to doubt it, it would appear that your decision is being ignored.

From the information set forth in my letters mentioned above, I am unable to see that the Roman Catholic Church has any claim whatever on the children in question, and it will be appreciated if you will advise me of any information you may have received which alters the situation as set forth in those communications.

With regard to the declaration of Sam Cook, the father of the children in question, made on December 7th, 1935, and forwarded to you with my letter of December 13th last, the Principal of our Onion Lake School, has written to me as follows:

"When Sam and his wife called at the School last December on a Saturday morning, he stated to me voluntarily, that he wanted his boy to come to our School and the girl next year; also, that he did not want his children to be separated, seeing that two of his children were now in residence here. I called in Ida Vandall, a grade nine pupil, who..."
was in the next room practising on the piano. I then took down his declaration, which Ida read over to him and he signed it in her presence. I sent a copy to you and the other I gave to the Indian Agent who sent it to the Department."

The Reverend Principal also furnishes the following information bearing on this case:

"Sam Cook has been Baptized, confirmed and married in the Anglican Faith.

Mary, his wife has been baptized in our Church.

All their children of school age have received their tuition under Anglican auspices.

Six of their children are buried in our cemetery.

None have ever entered the R.C. School before."

From the above information you will understand the difficulty confronting our Society in allowing this case to stand where it does at present.

In your letter of February 5th you kindly furnished me with a copy of a letter dated January 13th, 1936, and signed P. Harper, Chief. This Indian is known to me personally, and as the Principal of our Onion Lake School states that the Chief is supposed to have written his letter at the R.C. School and it was addressed to the Department from there. The Indian Agent had no knowledge of it, I am quite unable to attach any importance to it, and wish that the voluntary declaration made by the Indian father on December 7th last should be accepted as expressing his sincere desire to have his children Simon and Sarah admitted to our Society's School.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-8-10, of January 29, past, with further reference to Sam Cook's two children - Simon and Sarah, and in reply.

I would not care to suggest that the matter can now be considered settled as I feel sure that the C. of E. School authorities will register a vigorous protest unless they are admitted to their school.

After reading the enclosed copy of Sam Cook's letter to the Department under date of January 11th, I interviewed the reverend Mr. Ellis regarding it. Mr. Ellis does not speak the Cree language but he produced the interpreter who officiated at this meeting with Sam. She is Ida Vandal, a Grade 9 pupil in residence at the C. of E. School. She states positively that Sam requested Mr. Ellis to take Simon and Sarah into his school, and she confirmed everything in the statement that Sam had signed which was forwarded to the Department with my letter of December 10th. I am satisfied that this girl was telling the truth. I am quite sure that the Reverend Father Pratt has not tried to influence the Cooks. Sam Cook who had always sent his children to the C. of E. School, when he was apparently satisfied with the treatment they were getting, had a dispute with Mr. Ellis about two years ago over some cord work he was supplying to the school, and immediately after he changed his religion and requested the Reverend Father Pratt to accept his children as pupils. I confronted Sam today regarding his signed statement and he told me he wouldn't talk about it. He reiterated that he was a Roman Catholic and wanted his children to attend that school. I have found him to be unreliable and vacillating. My own opinion, which was confirmed by Chief Harper today, is that Sam is a Pagan and has no religious convictions.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

According to instructions received regarding children over sixteen and desired to be retained for a longer period, I submit through you to the Indian Dept. the list of those who I desire to keep for another year.

I insist for the girls because I always try to marry them as soon as they leave the school and by this to have a better result of the formation received at the school.

160 Gabriel Lewis 161 Frog Lake Alta.
This boy needs a more complete training and his parents are very poor and can hardly support themselves. The boy is well gifted and is doing very good. He strongly wishes to stay.

164 Johnny Badger 17 Keeheewin Alta.
The boy is not very strong and another year in the school will do him good. He is a very good boy and well gifted and is a good student.

196 George Horse 161 Thunderechild Indian Reserve Sask.
This boy is an orphan and has no place to go. Both his parents are dead. I am satisfied with him and he behaves good here. Some Indians will take care of him when he will leave the school for good. It will be a good thing to keep him here again as he is too young to be left alone among other people.

218 Edward Cardinal 17 Keewatin Alta.
This boy is an orphan and has been looked upon by an Halfbreed family who is very poor. He has attended school not quite two years. His brother after he be through with the school will take him with him and look after and will not allow him to leave the Reserve again. For the very benefit of the boy he should be kept in the school another year.

239 Philip Mouswa 161 Onion-Lake.
This boy is an orphan boy and only a very aunt look after him. I wish to keep him longer here.

0168 Mary Wolfe 18 Onion-Lake.
Her mother dead and has stayed at the school during her vacations for the last five years. Her father is away from the reserve and by now has nobody to look after her. She will be exposed if she is left alone. After finishing she will get married as I found her a good pupil. An "Expupil" I will appreciate if permission is given to keep her until she gets married.

0175 Nora Chogan 18 Onion-Lake.
She is another orphan girl and for the very same reasons I will like to keep her here until she gets married during the year.

0206 Genevieve Desjardins 161 Cold-Lake.
She is a very good girl and wishes very strongly to stay at the school. Her parents are very poor.
L.J.C. & M.I.

0223 Isabel Lapeel--- Frog-Lake Alta.
She is an orphan girl and has stayed at the school during vacation for the last four years. She is a very good girl and will get married sometimes during the year. I will like to keep her until then.

0224 Anna Motchowiyiniw 16½ Frog-Lake, Alta.
She is an orphan and no parents. Her poor Grand-Mother looks after her, and the old lady is very destitute. I cannot leave this girl stay home and exposed.

0226 Virginie Wolfe 15½ Onion-Lake.
She is an orphan with both parents dead. Only an aged old Grand Mother and very destitute looks after her. Permission to keep her will be greatly appreciated. She has no home as her GrandMother stays with other folks.

Dear Mr Phelan, if I ask the favor to keep the children mentioned in my list it is for the very benefit of these children and I know with experience that it is not without reason that I insist to keep them. I have spoken to our local Indian Agent before writing this letter and again I read it to him after and he strongly approves all what I have said about each case.

I do my very best to help all the Ex-Pupils and I try also to marry them as soon as they leave school especially the girls and this to keep them away from the habit of the old folke. In every case when a big girl from the school marries here I do my share to help her by buying what is necessary to start home.

Therefore I will be pleased and will appreciate very sincerely if all those whom I apply to keep will be granted.

Unclese to say that you are always welcome here in our school and I will be glad that you see by yourself the work done in behalf of the Indian children of the surrounding Indian Reserves.

With the hope of receiving a favorable reply

I am Yours very truly

ST. ANTHONY'S SCHOOL

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-8-10, of the 18th ultimo, with reference to the admission of Mrs. A. Collin's children to the R. C. Indian Residential School.

You will note by the last returns that there are 153 enrolled at this school while its capacity is but 120. The Collins children are breeds as stated, their mother being a treaty Indian. At present there are 15 breeds enrolled and in residence at the R. C. School. The Collins family have been living for some months on the Frog Lake reserve, but are really trespassers, and are sending their children to the Indian Day School there, where they are the envy of the Indian children owing to their good wearing apparel, having been outfitted by the Alberta Government.

These people are provincial charges and are getting relief from the province. They have no fixed abode, simply transients. The Frog Lake Indians have requested me to have the Collins removed from their reserve. If the present rate of breed admission to this school continues it will only be a matter of time before the Indian children will be crowded out.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I wish you to refer to the Department's letter No. 115-8-10, dated the 3rd of June regarding their decision of the two Cook children.

The parents brought these two children here yesterday morning and asked me (before a witness) to have them admitted into our school, stating that they wanted them to be with Edwin and Katherine, their brother and sister who are in residence here.

I refused to admit them, chiefly because of the letter above, stating that Sam had informed the Department through the Indian Agent that he was a Roman Catholic. He said that he was not, and could never be. I, therefore, advised him to tell the Department so, through the Indian Agent, but he stated he was afraid that the Indian Agent would not do it.

I then left for Lloydminster to get some engine repairs from the railway station. When I arrived back that evening, the two letters attached were left for me at the house.

Under the following dates - 24th Jan., 3rd and 30th of March last letters of protest regarding their admittance into the R.C. School were sent to you.

On the 4th and 9th of December last, letters and statements were sent to prove without a shadow of doubt that the Cooks have and were always recognised as Anglicans. As recently as 6th April last I was called upon to bury a granddaughter of the Cooks.

Mr. Craven of Turtleford baptized a Cook child less than a month ago, on the Thunderchild's Reserve where the Cooks were visiting.

In view of the letters received, I would ask that the whole question be considered again by the Department.

Yours truly,

(sgd) Henry Ellis. Principal.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Field Secretary of the M.S.C.C., in which he enclosed copy of a letter, dated September 25th, 1936, from Rev. Henry Ellis, Principal of the Onion Lake C.H. Indian Residential School, with regard to the two Cook children. The letter from Mr. Ellis reads, in part, as follows:

"The parents brought these two children here yesterday morning and asked me (before a witness) to have them admitted into our school, stating that they wanted them to be with Edwin and Katherine, their brother and sister, who are in residence here.

"I refused to admit them, chiefly because of the letter above, stating that Sam had informed the Department through the Indian Agent that he was a Roman Catholic. He said that he could not and could never be. I, therefore, advised him to tell the Department so through the Indian Agent, but he stated he was afraid that the Indian Agent would not do it."

It is presumed that the letter refers to Simon and Sarah Cook, whose admission to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School was approved by official letter of June 3rd last. In consideration of quarterly return of the Onion Lake R.C. School, it is noted that the Principal requested and received grant for each of these children for the full September quarter. It is, therefore, understood that they were present in that school during that quarter. Under these circumstances, the Department cannot understand the statement made in Reverend Mr. Ellis' letter that the parents brought the two children to the Onion Lake C.H. School on September 24th.

Please let me have an immediate report regarding these children, stating whether or not they are, at present, in the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School.

Mr. Minister,

I wish to recommend to your sympathetic attention Mr. Arthur Paquette, of Grand Centre, Cold Lake, Alberta. He is very poor and I am aware of his condition, for having employed him here at Mission Goff, commonly known as Cold Lake Indian Reserve, and for having visited him often.

He is married to a full-blooded Montagnaise Indian. He has 11 children, 10 of whom are living at home. All have been born on Cold Lake Indian Reserve, and until the last few years, lived on the Reserve when he bought a patented homestead out of his hard work. However, even with his homestead, which is only a quarter of a mile square, he has to work outside to try and get a living for his family. He has not been able to do so, and this is why I hired him to help him. He is on relief, and even with his relief, he has not enough to provide clothing for his family and he has to seek Government assistance.

The purpose of my letter is as follows: He intends sending at least four of his children to the Indian School of Lac d'Oignon, St. Anthony's School, Onion Lake, Via Hoydminster, Sask., as none of his children have received any education. He cannot afford to pay school taxes. The school nearest to his home is 5½ miles and, naturally, much too far for the children to attend. Besides, as all those children were born on the Reserve and have lived almost all their lives on the Reserve and have been brought up as Indians and are without education, there is no reason why they should be refused. The Bonnyville police, at my request, is supposed to have sent a strong recommendation on my behalf to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa and in Saskatchewan. As we have not received any reply from either Government, I write to you directly asking you to admit to the Catholic school of St. Anthony, Lac d'Oignon, as they are Catholics. We have no reason to refuse them since they have a right to receive some education like the others and cannot go anywhere else.
If you wish to admit them to the school you can do it, if you do not want to, this is another thing, and they shall remain without education. I am asking you to accept them as soon as possible. In any event, I ask for an immediate reply advising me of their admission. I ask for such reply because I know you to be in a position to give it to me. You will find below the names and dates of birth of these four children whom I am recommending to be admitted to St. Anthony's School, Onion Lake, via Hoydminster, Sask.

Alice Paquette, April 10, 1924,
Charles, Jan. 6, 1926,
Bertha, August 15, 1928,
Marie Albertine, May 10, 1930.

In the hope that I shall receive an immediate reply, I am,

Yours truly,

(Signed) Thomas Pelletier, missionary,
Goff, Alberta.
Ottawa, December 7th, 1936.

Reverend Sir,-

I am directed to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, with reference to the children of Mr. Arthur Paquette.

Mr. Paquette's case is, no doubt, a very deserving one but, at the same time, I would point out that his children cannot be considered wards of this Department. Under these circumstances, we are not prepared to approve their admission to the Onion Lake R. C. Indian Residential School.

If Mr. Paquette is unable to provide the necessary funds for the education of his children, responsibility for their education would appear to rest with the provincial authorities.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie.

Dear Sir,

In 1935, Sam Cook of the Onion Lake Band requested the admission of his children, Sarah and Simon, to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. Inquiry showed that older children of this man had been educated in the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School. At the time he applied for the admission of the two children to the Onion Lake R.C. School, Cook claimed to be a member of the Roman Catholic Church. There was considerable correspondence with Mr. Agent Hill and it was not until June, 1936, that the Department decided to accede to Cook's wishes and approve the admission of his two children to the Onion Lake R.C. School.

Last Fall, during the absence of the Principal of the Onion Lake R.C. School, the mother went to the school and was allowed to take the two children out for the day. She took them to the Onion Lake C.E. School and told the Principal of that school that she wanted them educated there. He communicated with Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D., Field Secretary of the M.S.C.C., who has written to the Department urging that the children be taken out of the Onion Lake R.C. School and placed in the Onion Lake C.E. School. This is another case of disagreement regarding the religious auspices under which these children should be educated. A similar case is being brought to your attention in another letter and a brief outline has been given regarding the information that has to be obtained and the facts that have to be kept in mind before a definite decision can be given.

On the occasion of your next visit to the Onion Lake Agency, the Department wishes you to interview all parties concerned and report fully whatever information you obtain, in order to assist us in making a final decision regarding the school in which the Cook children should be educated.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., Nov. 22nd, 1937.

Dear Sir;

Ref.#115-8-10-Sam Cook's children
Onion Lake School

I interviewed Dan Vanesse, interpreter, Onion Lake Agency; Dr. Hill, Agent; Mr. and Mrs. S. Cook and Mrs. Fox with reference to the above matter.

The interpreter stated that the reason Cook applied to have his children educated in the Roman Catholic school was that his, Cook's, wife was a Roman Catholic and that Cook had been a Roman Catholic until about 1900 when Mr. Matheson went to Onion Lake. At that time Cook, along with other Indians, went over to the Church of England.

He said that Cook remained with the Church of England and his family were educated in that school until 1935 when he returned to the Roman Catholic church and wanted to have his children educated in that church. At that time there were two of his children in the Church of England school.

Vanesse stated that Mrs. Cook had always been a Roman Catholic although she like others had joined the Church of England auxiliary, that Cook did not wish to return to the Roman Catholic church until he had a violent quarrel with Mr. Ellis, principal of the Church of England school about wood, at which time he took his bible back to Ellis and told him that he did not wish to have anything more to do with him.

R.A.Hoey, Esq.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Mr. Cook stated that he wants to stay with the Church of England now but that the other church is bothering him a lot. He said the reason he left the Church of England was that Mr. Ellis used to send the police for his children which he did not like. He states that he wants his children educated in the Church of England school as he and his wife intend to stay with that church and that he wants them all together. He at the same time stated that one of his reasons for wanting the children taken out of the Roman Catholic church was because his wife had had a quarrel with one of the sisters.

Mrs. Cook stated that she is now a member of the Church of England that she took communion with the Church of England at Onion Lake last fall at confirmation service. This was confirmed by both Dr. Hill and Mrs. Fox. She also stated that she intends to stay with the Church of England and wants the children educated there.

Dr. Hill confirms the statements made by Vanesse that prior to 1900 Cook was a Catholic, went over with others to the Church of England when Mr. Matheson came to Onion Lake and remained with the Church of England until he had the quarrel with Mr. Ellis when he again returned to the Roman Catholic church but is now attending the Church of England. He also confirms Mrs. Cook's statement that she, Mrs. Cook, took communion with the Church of England last fall. Dr. Hill at the same time points out that Cook in 1935 was just as positive that he would remain with the Roman Catholic as he is today that he will remain with the Church of England. The doctor also states that there was no attempt made to have the children removed from the Roman Catholic school until Mrs. Cook had the quarrel with one of the sisters and the principal.

This is in my opinion not a case of any deep religious convictions. I do not believe that it actually means anything to either Mr. or Mrs. Cook as to which school their children are educated in, except that they object having their children in a school with which they happen to be at odds at the time.

Cook places two of his children in the Church of England school, he then decided to go back to the Roman Catholic and placed two others there. Today he decides to go back to the Church of England and wants his children educated there. Tomorrow what?

It...........
It appears to me that not religious convictions but petty quarrels and over zeal, not in the interest of christianity but of denominationalism on the part of the churches has drawn the Department into a quarrel in which we should not be involved, and that the interests of all would be best served by leaving matters as they are, two children in the Church of England school and two children in the Roman Catholic school.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir;-

I beg to submit attached letter from Mr. Macdonald re Mabel Child.

Mr. Cockburn, Farming Instructor, reports that this girl is attending school regularly and that she has been kept at home in order that she might accompany the little boy to day school.

I would judge from this that they consider the boy too young to go alone and if the girl was not there the boy would also be sent to residential school.

It would appear to me that Mr. Macdonald in asking a definite ruling covering all such cases is not giving much consideration to the wishes of the parents or the expenditure of the Department. In cases where there are no day schools and the child is not being educated I do not think there should be any hesitation about insisting the child go to residential school, where there is a day school and the parents wish to send the child there, I believe they should be given sympathetic consideration.

In the present case this girl is attending day school and receiving her education at one-third of the cost to the Department, and personally I believe she should be left there.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,

Ottawa.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of August 30 and previous correspondence regarding two children of Sam Cook, the Department has received a very complete report from Inspector Robertson, which reads in part as follows:

"This is in my opinion not a case of any deep religious convictions. I do not believe that it actually means anything to either Mr. or Mrs. Cook as to which school their children are educated in, except that they object having their children in a school with which they happen to be at odds at the time.

Cook places two of his children in the Church of England school, he then decided to go back to the Roman Catholic and placed two others there. Today he decides to go back to the Church of England and wants his children educated there. Tomorrow what?"

It has been decided that the two children of Sam Cook who are at present in the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School should remain there. Instructions are being issued to Indian Agent Dr. Hill that the two children at present in the Onion Lake R.C. School should be discharged from that school at once and returned to their parents.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant in which you state that you recently interviewed Sam Cook who has advised you that he is a member of the Church of England and wishes his children to be under the auspices of that Church.

Under the circumstances, the Department is prepared to approve the admission of Simon and Sarah Cook to the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School, providing they are in good health. The necessary forms should be forwarded for our consideration.

In official letter of December 17, 1937, you were instructed to have the above mentioned two children returned to their parents from the Onion Lake R.C. School. Apparently this was done, because no grant has been requested at the Onion Lake R. C. School since that time. However, it is noted that they are still carrying the names of these children on the Return as Simon Cook, No. 272, and Sarah Cook, No. 0292. The names of both these children should not appear on the future Returns of the Onion Lake R. C. School.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan

he lodges a protest against the admittance of the Angli-
can Indian child Joseph Lloyd Dillon to the Roman

In support of this protest he points out
that this boy was "born on Nov. 3, 1932 and was baptized
by me on Dec. 4, 1936". He further points out that
as the father "was ill suffering with heart trouble
and the mother was not capable of looking after the
child", the father was anxious that this boy should
be placed in our Society's School with his two brothers.
The local Indian Agent thought that the boy was too
young for admission to any School, but subsequently
he allowed him to be placed, for the time being, in
the Roman Catholic School, but informed the Principal
of our Society's School "that he would not sign the
application when presented by the Roman Catholic
School authorities. Application has now been presented
to Ottawa and I wish to protest the lad's admission
into the Roman Catholic School".

As the Principal states that the Indian
Agent informed him at the time this boy was admitted
to the Roman Catholic School that he would see that he
was, in due course, returned to his home, no protest
was lodged with your Branch of Government at that time.
As an official application for his admission on a grant-
earning basis to the Roman Catholic School at Onion Lake

now appears to have been forwarded to your Department I am writing for the specific purpose of requesting that the protest of the Principal of our School be sympathetically considered, and that this boy be transferred to our School where he rightly belongs. In support of this request I desire to lay before you the following copy of a letter which the Principal of our Society's School addressed to the local Indian Agent on Feb. 29th, 1936:

"Dr. J.T. Hill,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Dear Sir:-

I have to protest against Joseph Lloyd Dillon, a child of the Anglican faith, age four years, the son of Douglas and Margaret Dillon, being admitted into the Roman Catholic School at Onion Lake. You will recall that the father was anxious to have this boy in our school about three months ago, to be with his two brothers. Because of this, I advised Douglas to take this matter up with you. You will also remember, that I also spoke to you and suggested that the boy could be taken into our school as a supernumerary pupil, but this suggestion did not meet with your approval on account of the tender age of the boy. As it is now the intention of the Roman Catholic authorities here to keep this boy in their school for three years, before making an official application, I have to protest against the boy being in residence at that institution. Should it be found that the boy is being neglected, then I beg to suggest that he be placed in the school where he rightly belongs with his two brothers. ........

Yours very truly,

(sgd) Henry Ellis

Principal."

As a very definite ruling has been laid down in the Indian Act with regard to the admission of Protestant Indian children to Protestant Schools and of Roman Catholic Indian children to Roman Catholic Schools, it is quite clear to me and to our Commission that endless confusion and discord can only be
avoided through the most careful observation on the part of all Indian Agents of that ruling.

In the case in question it seems quite clear from the information set forth in the letter of our Principal to the local Indian Agent, quoted above, that the boy should never have been admitted to the Roman Catholic School, and as a matter of common justice I beg to request that his immediate transfer to our Society's School be authorized.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant enclosing applications and certificates of health for the admission of certain children to the Onion Lake R.C. residential school.

In view of the information contained in your letter the admission of Archie Belly is approved.

The eligibility of Lloyd Wilfrid Dillon on religious grounds is doubtful and the Department is not prepared to approve his admission to any Indian residential school at the present time. You might communicate with this office regarding this boy in about 6 months time and at that time you should state in what school the father wishes him to be placed.

As you are aware from the contents of the circular letter forwarded to you some months ago the Department is averse to admitting halfbreed children to Indian residential schools. In the case of Joseph Peepeekoot it is noted that he was taken at birth by Chief Peepeekoot and it would, therefore, appear that the latter has adopted the boy. Under these circumstances it has been decided to approve the boy's admission to the Onion Lake R.C. school. However, it is felt that consideration should be given to having him admitted as a member of the Band. Such recommendation, of course, must be the subject of a separate communication.

Yours truly,

Dr. J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

On October 15th, 1938, I wrote to the Secretary of your Branch of Government regarding the Anglican Indian boy Joseph Lloyd Dillon, who had been admitted to the Roman Catholic School on the Onion Lake Reserve, and requested that he be transferred to our Society's School on the same Reserve.

In your reply on Oct. 20th, 1938, No. 115-8-10, you stated that you had advised the Indian Agent that you were not prepared to approve the admission of this boy to any Indian Residential School at that time, as he was only four years of age.

I have just received a letter from the Principal of our Onion Lake School, written on the 11th instant, in which he states that this Indian boy is still in the Roman Catholic School, and that any instructions you may have issued to the local Indian Agent regarding his return to his home have not been carried out.

As there does not appear to be any doubt whatever about the parents of this child being Anglican, and seeing that his two brothers are in our Society's School, (Miles being admitted in January, 1933, and John in December, 1934) I trust that, in fairness to our Society, the boy Joseph Lloyd Dillon may now be placed there also.
In previous communications I have endeavoured to point out the disadvantage at which our Society is placed in its Indian educational work, especially in the northern part of the province of Saskatchewan, through the lack of adequate number of residential school buildings. That disadvantage is still very keenly felt by our Commission and the members cannot but view with very serious concern any flagrant violation of the Indian Act as in the case of the Indian boy mentioned above and the apparent failure of your local representative to carry out your instructions concerning him.

I would respectfully ask, therefore, that prompt and decisive steps be taken to have this boy removed from the Roman Catholic School and transferred to our Society's School, where he rightly belongs.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School shows the following pupils over the age of 16:

No. 0187 Mary R. Dion No. 0228 Bella Waskewitch
" 0205 Rosa Janvier " 192 Rodrick Badger
" 0217 Mary L. Chozen

No application for retaining these children in your school appears to have been received and in this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

Rev. E. Pascal, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School,
Lloydminster, Sask.
I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Until further advised you should make arrangements for the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of 16 unless there are some very exceptional circumstances and in this event full particulars should be given to the Department and our permission obtained before such pupils reach the age of 16.

With the above in mind I desire to hear from you at the earliest possible date stating the date on which the pupils mentioned in the first part of this letter can be discharged from your school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sir:

I have the honour to report the following with regard to Emma Cardinal, aged 8 years, pupil No. 0316, of the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

She is the daughter of Arsene Cardinal, Indian Interpreter at the Agency, and Mr. Cardinal has requested permission to place his daughter in the Onion Lake Private School here this term. He has the permission of the School Board to do so, and Rev. E. Pascal, Principal of the R.C. Residential School, is willing to have the girl discharged from his school in order that she may attend the private school as the parents wish. I would be pleased to receive instruction from the Department.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith an application for the Admission of Jimmy Swan aged eight years, to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School.

This boy is the youngest son of Mrs. Margaret Swan, No. 140, Chipewyan band, and Thomas Swan, a whiteman, and although he is not in treaty I have signed the application for the following reasons. There are six boys in this family and the five oldest are already in the school (pupils Nos. 278-79-80-81 & 82). The father is dying and the children have lived the Indian mode of life with their grandfather, Gabriel Desjarlais, No. 123 of this band. Not to admit Jimmy would deprive him of all chance of an education.

Rev. Father Pascal has again made application for the admission of Lloyd Dillon to his school. In this connection I would respectfully refer to my letters of May 25 and June 27, past, even number, to which I have had no reply.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Dear Sir:

In checking the June quarter return of the Onion Lake R.C. School, it is noted that Louis Janvier, No. 245, is 17 years of age and Thos. Swan, No. 280, is 16½.

I also desire to refer you to my letter of November 10, 1941, approving Elmer Carlson, No. 224, and Genevieve Stanley, No. 0232, remaining in the school until June 30, 1942.

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-8-10, of the 16th instant, and to advise the Department that I visited the R.C. School today and discussed the matter of the discharge of those children who are over sixteen years of age with the Principal, Father Pascal.

The Principal informed me that applications for the discharge of Louis Janvier and Thomas Swan, pupils numbers 243 and 280, respectively, would be forwarded. The boys are now employed at their homes. Elmer Carlson, No. 224, has applied for enlistment in the Canadian Army and an application for his discharge from school will be made.

With reference to Genevieve Stanley, No. 0282, this girl has no home, and her father, who is a widower, wished her to stay at the school a while longer. However, either an application will be made for her discharge, or the Principal will submit a request for a further stay giving definite reasons for doing so.

I have the honour to be,

December 10, 1942.

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, you may inform the Principal of the Onion Lake R.C. School that the admission of Louis Bruce Naistus is approved. In regard to the applications for the admission of Florence and Agnes Swan, I have reviewed the previous correspondence with reference to the admission of other children of this family to the Onion Lake School and it is evident that, in view of the last ruling regarding the admission of half-breeds, these children are not eligible for admission as grant-earning pupils to an Indian residential school. In your letter of October 28, 1940, forwarding the application for the admission of Jimmy Swan, you stated that the father was dying and that the children had lived the Indian mode of life with their grandfather. The application form at that time was signed by the grandfather. The application forms for the two girls are signed by Harry Janise and your recent letter states that they have lived on the reserve all their lives. Is the father of these children dead? Is the mother actually living on the reserve, or is she simply passing off the children to various Indians in order to secure their admission to an Indian residential school? As intimated previously, we are really not responsible for the education of these children and, although we have dealt very generously with them in the past, I am inclined to feel that the time has now arrived when further favourable consideration cannot be given.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Onion Lake, Sask.
December 23rd., 1942.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your 115-8-10, of the 10th., instant, with reference to the applications for the admission of Florence and Agnes Swan to the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School, and to submit the following additional information in regard to their plight.

The father is still living although apparently at the point of death all the time. All the children (and the mother as well) live with their grandfather, Gabriel Desjarlais, No. 126, Chipewyan Band, and perhaps he should have signed the applications for Florence & Agnes. However, the applications were signed by Harry Janvier, Chief of the Band, evidently in the belief that he was helping to secure their admission to School.

For the above reasons I would again respectfully request favourable consideration for the admission of Florence and Agnes to School, along with their brothers.

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

On the March quarter return of the Onion Lake R.C. School the age of Elmer Carlson, No. 284, is shown as 17½ years. From the information given on the application form when he was first admitted, this boy is now 20 years of age. We have already granted permission for him to remain to the end of June and certainly we will be unable to pay any grant for him after that date. As a matter of fact he should be able to secure work immediately, due to the scarcity of labour.

Eric Carlson, No. 238, is shown on the March quarter return as 15½ and Louis Janvier, No. 243, is shown as 15½. From the information contained on the application forms for both these boys, the age of the former is now 17 and the age of the latter 19½. As stated above, there is no reason why these boys should not be able to secure work at the present time and the Principal should arrange for their immediate discharge.

Pupils 0272, 0282 and 0292 are over 16 years of age. The Principal should apply for their discharge at the end of June or, if he wishes to keep them for a further period, special application should be made to this office stating definitely the reasons for desiring them to remain.

I wish to refer to Pupil No. 0298, Mary Badger, of the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. The father Sam Badger, Headman, Keeheewin Reserve, made a request that his daughter be transferred to Blue Quills Indian Residential School, St. Paul, Alberta, as it is nearer home and her friends were attending that School. The request was made at the time of Mr Christianson's visit to the reserve on August 12th., and since then I have seen Father Latour, Principal of Blue Quills, who was willing to accept her, and Father Pascal, Principal of the Onion Lake School, who was willing that the transfer be made. I would be pleased to receive word that the Department approves of this change.

July 18, 1944.

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Onion Lake R.C. School:

Sarah Martial          Mathilda Waskewitch
Agnes Choan            Margaret Jane Lewis

We also approve the discharge of pupils numbered 0285 and 0329. Pupils numbered 236 and 0272 may remain in the school for another year.

We have carefully noted the information you supply regarding Joseph Lawrence Masson and Wilfrid Masson. This is exactly the same information that you gave in your letter of January 21 last regarding Clara Masson. In reviewing these applications the Department feels that these two boys are not eligible for admission and we further feel that a mistake was made in approving the admission of the girl last January. However, you might let me have some further information. Are all three of these children legitimate or illegitimate? It is impossible to tell from your letter. Has the children's father made any provision for them during the past few years? We are prepared to consider further information but, as stated above, we are not satisfied that their status entitles them to admission to a residential school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch - Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, File No. 115-8-10, with reference to the application for admission of Joseph Lawrence Masson and Wilfrid Masson, brothers of Clara Masson, pupil No. 0364.

All three children were illegitimate but on June 14th, 1943, the parents were married. The father of these children works around the country as a labourer and no doubt contributes to their living, but he is in no position whatever to make provision for any education for them. The children live on the Onion Lake reserve with their grandmother and I do not know of any other way for them to get a little education than by being admitted to the Residential school as grant-earning pupils.

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
August 3, 1944.

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Sask.

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, with further reference to the children of Archie Masson. Very careful consideration has been given to the contents of your letters of January 21, 1944, and July 27, 1944. It is evident that this family cannot be considered Indians as defined by the Indian Act and consequently the children are not eligible for admission as grant-earning pupils to any Indian residential school.

You should, therefore, inform the Principal of the Onion Lake R.C. School that no further grant will be paid for Clara Masson and that the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of Joseph Lawrence Masson and Wilfrid Masson to any Indian residential school.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Reverend Sir:

We have found it necessary to send back your December Quarter Return. It is evident that you have not carefully reviewed Circular Letter of December 29th, 1944, nor has any attention been given to the column on the right hand side of the Return.

The name of Joseph Jimmy, No. 372 was shown on your September Quarter Return but no grant was requested for him during that Quarter. On the December Return you asked for a grant for 92 days but on Form I.A. 411, which accompanied the Return, you state that this boy entered the school on October 15th, 1945. If the latter date is correct you are only entitled to a grant from October 15th to the end of December. On the Return you show that Joseph Jimmy entered the school on 21st May, 1945. You will note that the information given regarding this boy is not consistent.

What has been stated regarding the difference between the information given on the Return and the information given on the Form I.A. 411 in the case of Joseph Jimmy, applies also to pupils No. 373, 374 and 375.

On Form 411 and on the Return you state that pupils 0375, and 0376 entered the school on October 15th. This entitles you to a grant from that date to the end of the Quarter which is 77 days instead of 92 days as requested.

Pupil 0377 is shown both on the Return and Form I.A. 411 as having entered the school on October 27th. If this information is correct you should only be entitled grant from that date to the end of December and not for 92 days.

In the case of pupils 0384 and 0389 it appears both from the Return and Form I.A. 411 that these girls entered the school on the same date in December although you do not give the exact date but in each case you requested 92 days. Again may I point out that if the date of admission is correct, you are only entitled to a grant from that date to the end of the Quarter.

All these returns are being very carefully scrutinized by the Auditor General at this time and we simply must have them correct. The information on the form I.A. 411 should coincide exactly with the information on the return. In view of the errors we are sending back the return for correction. Arrangements will be made to allow you part-payment on the December Quarter grants.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

The Principal of the School told me of your letter regarding to Gordon Thunderchild.

I thought I had some right to put him in that school as he has already change his religion and I am the only one that has ever clothe him with the help of my children here.

Because I separated from Philip Thunderchild five months before Gordon was born. Because he nearly killed me knocking me down and then kicking me some of the people of Thunderchild saw the condition I was and when I got here the lumps on my head could still be felt and seen. I was here in Onion Lake when Gordon was born and I stayed here for 4 years and then I went back to Philip Thunderchild. I stayed with him for 1 year and then got sick for lack of warm clothing and good food. I went to Prince Albert Sanitorium. I stayed there for 2 years. I left Gordon there at Thunderchild. I used to send them clothing that I have made up for the two boys from the money I had receive from my children here and made some of the money from my sewing, and when I got back to Thunderchild from the Hospital they still had the clothing I had send them no other clothing for them to change. And when I got there I was surprised at the grub they had only bannak and lard. I still stayed for 3 mos. eating the same food nor getting any clothing for me and the boys. The farmer Instructor came to coax him to work but he just laid around so I left him again with my boy Gordon, and one thing too we did not get any of our treaty money not even John George MacDonald's money.

He has never clothe nor given any money to Gordon so I believe I am the one to see Gordon in the best school I know off.

So I would like you to let him remain where he is without further interference. I have been staying with my daughter and got them to write for me.

Sincerely,

Mrs. Edith Thunderchild
Philip
Thunderchild Reserve,
January 7th, 1946

C.S. Bell Esq.,
Indian Agent, Battleford, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Re: Gordon Thunderchild

I discussed this problem with the Father of the above noted child and he states that he does not want the child to go to the Anglican School at Prince Albert. He would rather see the child left at the School at Onion Lake until the summer holidays. His desire is that he have the child with him on the Reserve.

With regard to the question asked by Mr. Whelan of the Training Division as to who has been maintaining the child, I would say that the honours are fairly evenly divided. During the year that she lived with her husband after the child Gordon was born and during her stay in the San he was maintained by the Father. Since she left and went to live at Onion Lake the Mother has maintained the child. Apparently we are back where we started from. It might be just as well if we advised the Bishop at Prince Albert that the Father of the child will not accede to sending him to the Anglican Boarding School. The question boils down to the fact, has the Mother or the Father the prior claim on the child?

Yours truly,

Wm. Cockburn

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter #115-8-10 dated January 16, 1946, along with the Quarterly Return of September 30th to December 31st, 1945.

Regarding Joseph Jimmy No. 372 and 374 Johnny Carter, we wish to state that the date on the Return marked May 21st, 1945 is an error on the part of the secretary using the repetition sign ";", it would otherwise have been marked as 10-15-45 which was written corresponding No. 374 and 12-15-45 for No. 373. We wish to state that these dates are those of the admission as received from Ottawa through the agency #115-8-10. As we understand the date of the pupils' arrival at school as stated in the admission form No. 1-A-406, is the date of entrance to School. Therefore the date of entrance of 372 is September 21, 1945. That of 373 is September 30th, 1945. The 92 day grant requested is thus correct.

The error in typing the two above pupils' dates as 10-15-45 naturally makes Richard Chocon No. He. 374, was meant to be registered as 12-15-45 that is referring to letter #115-8-10 from Ottawa. Date of admission from Ottawa was received from Onion Lake Agency by telephone as delivery of mail was not possible before a week. The exact day, the 19th, as you noticed was left out, the Agent inserted it on Form No. 1-A-411. However the date of entrance of 374 as on form No. 1-A-406 is Oct. 22, 1945, thus allowing 70 days grant.

The date of entrance of Samuel Moyah No. 375 is November 24th, 1945. This entitles us to 89 days grant. The same error was made about his admission date.

Referring to dates marked on Form 411 and on the Return of pupils 0375 Agnes Jimmy and 0376 Susan Jimmy the same error of taking admission dates from Ottawa are to be noticed. The entrance dates of both No. 0375 and 0376, is September 11th, 1945. They are therefore entitled to full grant of 92 days.

Pupil 0377 shown both on the Return and Form 1-A-411 as 10-27-45, is subject to the same explanation as above, date received from Onion Lake was used. The exact date of her entrance as shown on Form No. 1-A-406 is September 4th, 1945 and thus entitles to 92 days grant.
We notice with regret that even an error was made in inserting the Nos.of Julia Fatehegan and Edna Harper. To follow suite it should be 0379 instead of 0354 and that of Edna Harper 0379 instead of 0389. This will be corrected.

The same mistake as mentioned above was made in stating 10-27-45 for 0376 Julia Fatehegan. Her entrance was on October 22nd, 1945 and thus allows her 70 days.

That of Edna Harper 0379 is October 27th, 1945 and entitles to 66 days grant.

The long interval between dates of entrance and of admission by the Department is due to the forced delay in having the children examined by the doctor. We are frequently cut off from communication. The roads become impassable by mud and water in spring and summer, while in winter snow drifts barricade. The river cannot be crossed for long periods in spring and autumn. We trust that you will understand our handicaps.

We fully realize the mistakes made and humbly beg pardon for errors both in dates and days requested for Nos. 374, 375, 0378, 0379.

The Return and Form No.1/A-4 all corrected in red ink above each error is returned herewith, trusting that you will allow us the grant entitled.

Once more may we state that we will follow our Returns more closely to give you full satisfaction. Although it may appear to be so, no fraud was meant.

Thanking you for your kind cooperation on this matter, I remain,

Devotedly yours,

Rev. E. Pascal, c.m.i.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I received your letter # 115-8-10 (El) dated April 25, a week ago.

Re: truancy.

There has been but one real truancy case—a pupil who stayed away a considerable time. Besides this two boys ran away and were brought back by their own father the following morning. Their reason was that of a quarrel with an older boy. The matter was settled and everybody was satisfied.

During the Christmas holidays three girls ran away because they envied their companions at home on the reserve. We hardly could blame them for this.

Three or four others went away for no special reasons and were brought back inside of a few days.

We do our best to treat the children very kindly. Every possible means are taken to make the children understand their duties without the use of severe punishment. This method has proven very satisfactory.

Naturally, we have to do with Indian children and parents, who do not always understand the importance and need of an education and these problems therefore repeat themselves occasionally.

We hope that this is satisfactory explanation.

Yours truly,

Rev. Jules St. Pierre, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Re: School Children - Wabamum Reserve

With reference to your letter of November 6th, and my reply of November 18th, we are now advised that the thirteen children can be accommodated in the Blue Quills and Onion Lake R.C. Residential Schools.

As we infer from the contents of your letter of November 6th that these children are not receiving any education now, we would appreciate it if you would instruct Superintendent Robertson to arrange for the admission of the children to the two schools mentioned.

If at any time in the future a day school is established on the reserve, we can then consider whether the children should be allowed to remain at home to attend the day school.

We have your letter of the 20th instant with reference to Sandy Standinghorn and David Jimmy Junior.

Dear Mr. Bell,

As an answer to your letter asking for more information concerning the recommendation for the discharge of Sandy Standinghorn and David Jimmy I would say that the main reason for their leaving the school is their love for freedom. Seeing that their parents will not do anything about it, they feel they can stay away from school as long as they wish.

Mr. Jimmy has told me himself that his son just did not want to come to school.

For Sandy Standinghorn in particular, we have many proofs showing that he is a menace to the school. His misbehavior is a cause of scandal and bad example for others.

The boys have reported that Sandy has told them in plain words "I have set the fire in the other school (meaning Delmas) and I will set it here too." He has already made two attempts to set the fire here since. The fact that he did not succeed does not mean that there is nothing to it, I believe.

He has left school three times already and was picked up twice. The third time he left, he has stolen articles from a store in Paradise Hill and tried to sell them to people afterwards for less than their value. Complaints were brought to us by the store owner himself. A lady had tried to take care of him, but he escaped from there the first chance he had, leaving his rubbers behind, this proving that he was from here, and who he was.

Now Mr. Bell, I hope these informations will
be judged sufficient to make his discharge possible.

Sincerely yours,

"Rev. Jules T. Pierre"
O.M.I.,
Principal.
Battleford, Sask.
January 12, 1949.

Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Replying to your letter No. 659-10(E.1) of the 29th ultimo, with reference to Sandy Standinghorn and David Jimmy, Jr., who have absconded on several occasions from St. Anthony's Indian Residential School, Onion Lake. I am enclosing copy of letter received from the Principal regarding these children, and await your further instructions.

These boys apparently will not settle down to study, no doubt if sent back to school would abscond at first opportunity. If they should during severe weather there is the danger of freezing to death if exposed for any great length of time. While parents appear to be indifferent about insisting children remain in school, they would be the first to make a howl if anything should happen to cause suffering.

At first opportunity I will interview Sandy Standinghorn about remarks he apparently has made to others; "I have set the fire in the other school (meaning Delmas) and I will set it here too". I am doubtful as his name was never mentioned during the investigation of the Delmas fire.

C.S. Bell
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

In answer to your last letter, concerning Emma Cardinal, who is over age and not in the class room, I am sorry to say that this was overlooked, as I was sure that it was arranged on time.

Emma has a step-mother and had asked to remain in the school for manual training all day, especially for sewing, knitting, etc. She has talent for that kind of work and we encouraged and taught her as much of it as she wanted.

School Attendance - Frog Lake Reserve

The Inspector of Schools in his most recent report, comments on the poor attendance of many pupils at the Frog Lake Indian Day School.

It is understood that there are on the reserve a number of pupils who use as an excuse for their poor attendance the distance of their homes from the school.

The new school as sited will not obviate this excuse. It is considered, accordingly, that steps should be taken to arrange for the attendance at appropriate residential schools of those children whose homes are beyond the legal limit for pupil-travel. The attendance of those within a reasonable radius of the Day school should be enforced in the usual way.

There may be still accommodation for Roman Catholic pupils at the Onion Lake Residential school. For children of other denominations it is possible that accommodation still exists at the Edmonton residential school. Please make early investigation of the accommodation available and of the children for whom it should be arranged and take action accordingly.

Re: Residential School Attendance & Family Allowance Payments.

Reference your SO-1 of the 8th instant, this is to advise that the difficulties experienced are as follows:

(1) At the opening of each school season (Sept.) a number of families move off the Reserves for harvesting and fall work, thus they cannot all be contacted.

(2) All parents with children attending Residential Schools, that can be contacted, are advised from two to three weeks in advance of the opening dates and this word is circulated in every way possible, but results are poor.

(3) On the exact date that the children are to return to Residential Schools, a member of our staff is present at the various railway stations to obtain a record of those returning for Family Allowance purposes but we do not get the full co-operation of the parents in this respect, and in such cases it is necessary to have Family Allowances suspended until the date of return is known.

(4) Many parents send their children back to the Residential Schools at various intervals after the opening date and in the majority of cases we are not notified by the parents or the Principals of the schools to which children have returned, nor the date of admission.

(5) The only means of obtaining a true list of admissions and discharges for Family Allowance purposes has been to contact the Principals on the first of each week direct by telephone, or calling in person at the school for this record.

Further to the above, I wish to advise that the Blue Quills Residential School is the only one that keeps this office posted on returns.
For this new school season we have not obtained any returns from the Edmonton Residential School nor the Onion Lake Residential School both of which have children from this Agency thus causing unnecessary suspensions of Family Allowances and the only means of correcting this delay is by direct contact with the payee.

(signed) W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

Enclosed please find copy of a letter received today from Mr. Taylor of the Saddle Lake Agency concerned, in part, with the difficulty experienced by him in securing information of the admission and discharge of children in his agency attending the Onion Lake Residential School.

A special problem exists in Residential Schools attended by children from more than one agency, and in such cases it has been found necessary to amend our instructions concerning the completion of Form I.A. 1069.

Would you, therefore, arrange for the nearest Superintendent to interview the Principal of the Onion Lake School and explain to him the difficulty being experienced by Mr. Taylor. The Principal should be requested to show at the top of Form I.A. 1069 where "Agency" appears the name of the agency from which the child comes, rather than the agency in which the school is located. A copy of the form should be sent to each of the Indian Superintendents concerned, after completion of columns 1, 2, 3, 4, and, if possible, 5. The Indian Superintendents on receipt of their copy of the form will complete the last three columns and forward to the Regional Director for action.

The above procedure ensures that each Superintendent with children attending this school receives prompt advice of the admission and discharge of such children and can then relay this information to the Regional Director for the necessary adjustments in Family Allowances payments.
Your co-operation in ensuring that the Principal of the Onion Lake School is fully aware of the procedure to be followed in using this form, particularly in regard to children attending from the Saddle Lake Agency, will be very much appreciated.

Please forward a brief report of the interview with the School Principal at your convenience.
